column3: 1)	" Gwen
column4: I want to thank you
column5: and I want to thank the folks here at Case Western Reserve for hosting this tonight. It's a very important event
column6: and they've done a superb job of putting it together. It's important to look at all of our developments in Iraq within the broader context of the global war on terror. And
column7: after 9/11
column8: it became clear that we had to do several things to have a successful strategy to win the global war on terror
column9: specifically that we had to go after the terrorists wherever we might find them
column10: that we also had to go after state sponsors of terror
column11: those who might provide sanctuary or safe harbor for terror. And we also then finally had to stand up democracies in their stead afterwards
column12: because that was the only way to guarantee that these states would not again become safe harbors for terror or for the development of deadly weapons.  Concern about Iraq specifically focused on the fact that Saddam Hussein had been
column13: for years
column14: listed on the state sponsor of terror
column15: that they he had established relationships with Abu Nidal
column16: who operated out of Baghdad; he paid $25
column17: 000 to the families of suicide bombers; and he had an established relationship with Al Qaida. Specifically
column18: look at George Tenet
column19: the CIA director's testimony before the Committee on Foreign Relations two years ago when he talked about a 10-year relationship.  The effort that we've mounted with respect to Iraq focused specifically on the possibility that this was the most likely nexus between the terrorists and weapons of mass destruction.  The biggest threat we faced today is the possibility of terrorists smuggling a nuclear weapon or a biological agent into one of our own cities and threatening the lives of hundreds of thousands of Americans.  What we did in Iraq was exactly the right thing to do. If I had it to recommend all over again
column20: I would recommend exactly the same course of action. The world is far safer today because Saddam Hussein is in jail
column21: his government is no longer in power. And we did exactly the right thing.

column3: for moderating this debate. Thank you to the folks of Case Western and all the people in Ohio for having us here.  Mr. Vice President
column4: you are still not being straight with the American people. I mean
column5: the reality you and George Bush continue to tell people
column6: first
column7: that things are going well in Iraq -- the American people don't need us to explain this to them
column8: they see it on their television every single day. We lost more troops in September than we lost in August; lost more in August than we lost in July; lost more in July than we lost in June.  The truth is
column9: our men and women in uniform have been heroic. Our military has done everything they've been asked to do.  And it's not just me that sees the mess in Iraq. There are Republican leaders
column10: like John McCain
column11: like Richard Lugar
column12: like Chuck Hagel
column13: who have said Iraq is a mess and it's getting worse. And when they were asked why
column14: Richard Lugar said because of the incompetence of the administration.  What Paul Bremer said yesterday is they didn't have enough troops to secure the country. They also didn't have a plan to win the peace. They also didn't put the alliances together to make this successful.  We need a fresh start. We need a president who will speed up the training of the Iraqis
column15: get more staff in for doing that. We need to speed up the reconstruction so the Iraqis see some tangible benefit. We need a new president who has the credibility
column16: which John Kerry has
column17: to bring others into this effort.

column1: We've made significant progress in Iraq. We've stood up a new government that's been in power now only 90 days. The notion of additional troops is talked about frequently
column2: but the point of success in Iraq will be reached when we have turned governance over to the Iraqi people; they have been able to establish a democratic government. They're well on their way to doing that. They will have free elections next January for the first time in history. We also are actively
column3: rapidly training Iraqis to take on the security responsibility.  Those two steps are crucial to success in Iraq. They're well in hand
column4: well under way. And I'm confident that
column5: in fact
column6: we'll get the job done.

column2: there is no connection between the attacks of September 11th and Saddam Hussein. The 9/11 Commission has said it. Your own secretary of state has said it. And you've gone around the country suggesting that there is some connection. There is not.  And in fact the CIA is now about to report that the connection between Al Qaida and Saddam Hussein is tenuous at best. And
column3: in fact
column4: the secretary of defense said yesterday that he knows of no hard evidence of the connection.  We need to be straight with the American people.

column1: Here's what it means: It means that Saddam Hussein needed to be confronted. John Kerry and I have consistently said that. That's why we voted for the resolution. But it also means it needed to be done the right way. And doing it the right way meant that we were prepared; that we gave the weapons inspectors time to find out what we now know
column2: that in fact there were no weapons of mass destruction; that we didn't take our eye off the ball
column3: which are Al Qaida
column4: Osama bin Laden
column5: the people who attacked us on September the 11th. Now
column6: remember
column7: we went into Afghanistan
column8: which
column9: by the way
column10: was the right thing to do. That was the right decision. And our military performed terrifically there.  But we had Osama bin Laden cornered at Tora Bora. We had the 10th Mountain Division up in Uzbekistan available. We had the finest military in the world on the ground. And what did we do?  We turned -- this is the man who masterminded the greatest mass murder and terrorist attack in American history. And what did the administration decide to do?  They gave the responsibility of capturing and/or killing Saddam -- I mean Osama bin Laden to Afghan warlords who
column11: just a few weeks before
column12: had been working with Osama bin Laden.  Our point in this is not complicated: We were attacked by Al Qaida and Osama bin Laden.  We went into Afghanistan and very quickly the administration made a decision to divert attention from that and instead began to plan for the invasion of Iraq.  And these connections -- I want the American people to hear this very clearly. Listen carefully to what the vice president is saying. Because there is no connection between Saddam Hussein and the attacks of September 11th -- period.  The 9/11 Commission has said that's true. Colin Powell has said it's true. But the vice president keeps suggesting that there is. There is not. And
column13: in fact
column14: any connection with Al Qaida is tenuous at best.

column1: The senator has got his facts wrong. I have not suggested there's a connection between Iraq and 9/11
column2: but there's clearly an established Iraqi track record with terror. And the point is that that's the place where you're most likely to see the terrorists come together with weapons of mass destruction
column3: the deadly technologies that Saddam Hussein had developed and used over the years.  Now
column4: the fact of the matter is
column5: the big difference here
column6: Gwen
column7: is they are not prepared to deal with states that sponsor terror. They've got a very limited view about how to use U.S. military forces to defend America.  We heard Senator Kerry say the other night that there ought to be some kind of global test before U.S. troops are deployed preemptively to protect the United States. That's part of a track record that goes back to the 1970s when he ran for Congress the first time and said troops should not be deployed without U.N. approval. Then
column8: in the mid-'80s
column9: he ran on the basis of cutting most of our major defense programs. In 1991
column10: he voted against Desert Storm.  It's a consistent pattern over time of always being on the wrong side of defense issues.  A little tough talk in the midst of a campaign or as part of a presidential debate cannot obscure a record of 30 years of being on the wrong side of defense issues.  And they give absolutely no indication
column11: based on that record
column12: of being wiling to go forward and aggressively pursue the war on terror with a kind of strategy that will work
column13: that will defeat our enemies and will guarantee that the United States doesn't again get attacked by the likes of Al Qaida.

column2: we've never let up on Osama bin Laden from day one. We've actively and aggressively pursued him. We've captured or killed thousands of Al Qaida in various places around the world and especially in Afghanistan. We'll continue to very aggressively pursue him
column3: and I'm confident eventually we'll get him. The key to success in Afghanistan has been
column4: again
column5: to go in and go after the terrorists
column6: which we've done

column8: in effect sponsors
column9: if you will

column11: two and a half years ago
column12: six months after we went into Afghanistan announced that it was chaotic
column13: the situation was deteriorating
column14: the warlords were about to take over. Here we are
column15: two and a half years later
column16: we're four days away from a democratic election
column17: the first one in history in Afghanistan. We've got 10 million voters who have registered to vote
column18: nearly half of them women.  That election will put in place a democratically elected government that will take over next December.  We've made enormous progress in Afghanistan
column19: in exactly the right direction
column20: in spite of what John Edwards said two and a half years ago. He just got it wrong.  The fact is
column21: as we go forward in Afghanistan
column22: we will pursue Osama bin Laden and the terrorists as long as necessary. We're standing up Afghan security forces so they can take on responsibility for their own security. We'll keep U.S. forces there -- we have about 16
column23: 000 there today -- as long as necessary
column24: to assist the Afghans in terms of dealing with their security situation. But they're making significant progress. We have President Karzai
column25: who is in power. They have done wonders writing their own constitution for the first time ever. Schools are open. Young girls are going to school. Women are going to vote. Women are even eligible to run for office. This is major
column26: major progress. There will be democracy in Afghanistan
column27: make no doubt about it. Freedom is the best antidote to terror.

column1: Someone did get it wrong. But it wasn't John Kerry and John Edwards. They got it wrong. When we had Osama bin Laden cornered

column7: first.  We will keep this country safe. He defended this country as a young man
column8: he will defend this country as president of the United States.  He also said very clearly that he will never give any country veto power over the security of the United States of America.  Now
column9: I know the vice president would like to pretend that wasn't said
column10: and the president would too. But the reality is it was said.  Here's what's actually happened in Afghanistan
column11: regardless of this rosy scenario that they paint on Afghanistan
column12: just like they do with Iraq. What's actually happened is they're now providing 75 percent of the world's opium.  Not only are they providing 75 percent of the world's opium
column13: large-cut parts of the country are under the control of drug lords and warlords. Big parts of the country are still insecure.  And the reality is the part of Afghanistan
column14: eastern Afghanistan
column15: where Osama bin Laden is
column16: is one of the hardest places to control and the most insecure
column17: Gwen.

column1: Twenty years ago we had a similar situation in El Salvador. We had -- guerrilla insurgency controlled roughly a third of the country
column3: 000 people dead
column4: and we held free elections. I was there as an observer on behalf of the Congress. The human drive for freedom
column5: the determination of these people to vote
column6: was unbelievable. And the terrorists would come in and shoot up polling places; as soon as they left
column7: the voters would come back and get in line and would not be denied the right to vote.  And today El Salvador is a whale of a lot better because we held free elections.  The power of that concept is enormous. And it will apply in Afghanistan
column8: and it will apply as well in Iraq.

column1: The vice president just said that we should focus on state sponsors of terrorism. Iran has moved forward with its nuclear weapons program. They're more dangerous today than they were four years ago. North Korea has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program
column2: gone from one to two nuclear weapons to six to eight nuclear weapons. This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran
column3: the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet.  It's a mistake. We should not only not lift them
column4: we should strengthen those sanctions.

column3: first
column4: he said in the same segment -- I don't remember precisely where it was connected with what you just read -- but he said
column5: point blank
column6: ""We will never give anyone a veto over the security of the United States of America."" What he's saying is we're going to go back to the proud tradition of the United States of America and presidents of the United States of America for the last 50 to 75 years.  First
column7: we're going to actually tell the American people the truth. We're going to tell them the truth about what's happening.  We're not going to suggest to them that things are going well in Iraq or anyplace else when
column8: in fact
column9: they're not.  We're going to make sure that the American people know the truth about why we are using force and what the explanation for it is.  And it's not just the American people. We're also going to make sure that we tell the world the truth.  Because the reality is
column10: for America to lead
column11: for America to do what it's done for 50 years before this president and vice president came into office
column12: it is critical that we be credible.  It is critical that they believe that when America takes action
column13: they can trust what we're doing
column14: what we say
column15: what we say at the United Nations
column16: what we say in direct conversations with leaders of the world -- of other countries.  They need to know that the credibility of the United States is always good
column17: because they will not follow us without that.  And unfortunately
column18: we're seeing the consequences of that right now.  It's one of the reasons that we're having so much difficulty getting others involved in the effort in Iraq.  You know
column19: we've taken 90 percent of the coalition casualties. American taxpayers have borne 90 percent of the costs of the effort in Iraq.  And we see the result of there not being a coalition: The first Gulf war cost America $5 billion. We're at $200 billion and counting.  John Kerry will never give up control over the security of the United States of America to any other country. We will not outsource our responsibility to keep this country safe.

column3: the 90 percent figure is just dead wrong. When you include the Iraqi security forces that have suffered casualties
column4: as well as the allies
column5: they've taken almost 50 percent of the casualties in operations in Iraq
column6: which leaves the U.S. with 50 percent
column7: not 90 percent. With respect to the cost
column8: it wasn't $200 billion. You probably weren't there to vote for that. But $120 billion is
column9: in fact
column10: what has been allocated to Iraq. The rest of it's for Afghanistan and the global war on terror.  The allies have stepped forward and agreed to reduce and forgive Iraqi debt to the tune of nearly $80 billion by one estimate. That
column11: plus $14 billion they promised in terms of direct aid
column12: puts the overall allied contribution financially at about $95 billion
column13: not to the $120 billion we've got
column14: but
column15: you know
column16: better than 40 percent. So your facts are just wrong
column17: Senator.  You also have a situation where you talk about credibility.  It's awfully hard to convey a sense of credibility to allies when you voted for the war and then you declared: Wrong war
column18: wrong place
column19: wrong time. You voted for the war
column20: and then you voted against supporting the troops when they needed the equipment
column21: the fuel
column22: the spare parts and the ammunition and the body armor.  You're not credible on Iraq because of the enormous inconsistencies that John Kerry and you have cited time after time after time during the course of the campaign. Whatever the political pressures of the moment requires
column23: that's where you're at. But you've not been consistent
column24: and there's no indication at all that John Kerry has the conviction to successfully carry through on the war on terror.

column1: May I respond briefly? What the vice president has just said is just a complete distortion. The American people saw John Kerry on Thursday night. They don't need the vice president or the president to tell them what they saw.  They saw a man who was strong
column3: who is resolute
column4: who made it very clear that he will do everything that has to be done to find terrorists
column5: to keep the American people safe.  He laid out his plan for success in Iraq
column6: made it clear that we were committed to success in Iraq. We have to be
column7: because we have troops on the ground there and because they have created a haven for terrorists.

column3: would be a lot more credible if there was a record to back it up. There isn't. And you cannot use ""talk tough"" during the course of a 90-minute debate in a presidential campaign to obscure a 30-year record in the United States Senate and
column4: prior to that by John Kerry
column5: who has consistently come down on the wrong side of all the major defense issues that he's faced as a public official.

column1: We heard Senator Kerry say the other night that there ought to be some kind of global test before U.S. troops are deployed preemptively to protect the United States. That's part of a track record that goes back to the 1970s when he ran for Congress the first time and said troops should not be deployed without U.N. approval. Then, in the mid-'80s, he ran on the basis of cutting most of our major defense programs. In 1991, he voted against Desert Storm.  It's a consistent pattern over time of always being on the wrong side of defense issues. column3: 1)	" Gwen
column4: I want to thank you
column5: and I want to thank the folks here at Case Western Reserve for hosting this tonight. It's a very important event
column6: and they've done a superb job of putting it together. It's important to look at all of our developments in Iraq within the broader context of the global war on terror. And
column7: after 9/11
column8: it became clear that we had to do several things to have a successful strategy to win the global war on terror
column9: specifically that we had to go after the terrorists wherever we might find them
column10: that we also had to go after state sponsors of terror
column11: those who might provide sanctuary or safe harbor for terror. And we also then finally had to stand up democracies in their stead afterwards
column12: because that was the only way to guarantee that these states would not again become safe harbors for terror or for the development of deadly weapons.  Concern about Iraq specifically focused on the fact that Saddam Hussein had been
column13: for years
column14: listed on the state sponsor of terror
column15: that they he had established relationships with Abu Nidal
column16: who operated out of Baghdad; he paid $25
column17: 000 to the families of suicide bombers; and he had an established relationship with Al Qaida. Specifically
column18: look at George Tenet
column19: the CIA director's testimony before the Committee on Foreign Relations two years ago when he talked about a 10-year relationship.  The effort that we've mounted with respect to Iraq focused specifically on the possibility that this was the most likely nexus between the terrorists and weapons of mass destruction.  The biggest threat we faced today is the possibility of terrorists smuggling a nuclear weapon or a biological agent into one of our own cities and threatening the lives of hundreds of thousands of Americans.  What we did in Iraq was exactly the right thing to do. If I had it to recommend all over again
column20: I would recommend exactly the same course of action. The world is far safer today because Saddam Hussein is in jail
column21: his government is no longer in power. And we did exactly the right thing.

column3: for moderating this debate. Thank you to the folks of Case Western and all the people in Ohio for having us here.  Mr. Vice President
column4: you are still not being straight with the American people. I mean
column5: the reality you and George Bush continue to tell people
column6: first
column7: that things are going well in Iraq -- the American people don't need us to explain this to them
column8: they see it on their television every single day. We lost more troops in September than we lost in August; lost more in August than we lost in July; lost more in July than we lost in June.  The truth is
column9: our men and women in uniform have been heroic. Our military has done everything they've been asked to do.  And it's not just me that sees the mess in Iraq. There are Republican leaders
column10: like John McCain
column11: like Richard Lugar
column12: like Chuck Hagel
column13: who have said Iraq is a mess and it's getting worse. And when they were asked why
column14: Richard Lugar said because of the incompetence of the administration.  What Paul Bremer said yesterday is they didn't have enough troops to secure the country. They also didn't have a plan to win the peace. They also didn't put the alliances together to make this successful.  We need a fresh start. We need a president who will speed up the training of the Iraqis
column15: get more staff in for doing that. We need to speed up the reconstruction so the Iraqis see some tangible benefit. We need a new president who has the credibility
column16: which John Kerry has
column17: to bring others into this effort.

column1: We've made significant progress in Iraq. We've stood up a new government that's been in power now only 90 days. The notion of additional troops is talked about frequently
column2: but the point of success in Iraq will be reached when we have turned governance over to the Iraqi people; they have been able to establish a democratic government. They're well on their way to doing that. They will have free elections next January for the first time in history. We also are actively
column3: rapidly training Iraqis to take on the security responsibility.  Those two steps are crucial to success in Iraq. They're well in hand
column4: well under way. And I'm confident that
column5: in fact
column6: we'll get the job done.

column2: there is no connection between the attacks of September 11th and Saddam Hussein. The 9/11 Commission has said it. Your own secretary of state has said it. And you've gone around the country suggesting that there is some connection. There is not.  And in fact the CIA is now about to report that the connection between Al Qaida and Saddam Hussein is tenuous at best. And
column3: in fact
column4: the secretary of defense said yesterday that he knows of no hard evidence of the connection.  We need to be straight with the American people.

column1: Here's what it means: It means that Saddam Hussein needed to be confronted. John Kerry and I have consistently said that. That's why we voted for the resolution. But it also means it needed to be done the right way. And doing it the right way meant that we were prepared; that we gave the weapons inspectors time to find out what we now know
column2: that in fact there were no weapons of mass destruction; that we didn't take our eye off the ball
column3: which are Al Qaida
column4: Osama bin Laden
column5: the people who attacked us on September the 11th. Now
column6: remember
column7: we went into Afghanistan
column8: which
column9: by the way
column10: was the right thing to do. That was the right decision. And our military performed terrifically there.  But we had Osama bin Laden cornered at Tora Bora. We had the 10th Mountain Division up in Uzbekistan available. We had the finest military in the world on the ground. And what did we do?  We turned -- this is the man who masterminded the greatest mass murder and terrorist attack in American history. And what did the administration decide to do?  They gave the responsibility of capturing and/or killing Saddam -- I mean Osama bin Laden to Afghan warlords who
column11: just a few weeks before
column12: had been working with Osama bin Laden.  Our point in this is not complicated: We were attacked by Al Qaida and Osama bin Laden.  We went into Afghanistan and very quickly the administration made a decision to divert attention from that and instead began to plan for the invasion of Iraq.  And these connections -- I want the American people to hear this very clearly. Listen carefully to what the vice president is saying. Because there is no connection between Saddam Hussein and the attacks of September 11th -- period.  The 9/11 Commission has said that's true. Colin Powell has said it's true. But the vice president keeps suggesting that there is. There is not. And
column13: in fact
column14: any connection with Al Qaida is tenuous at best.

column1: The senator has got his facts wrong. I have not suggested there's a connection between Iraq and 9/11
column2: but there's clearly an established Iraqi track record with terror. And the point is that that's the place where you're most likely to see the terrorists come together with weapons of mass destruction
column3: the deadly technologies that Saddam Hussein had developed and used over the years.  Now
column4: the fact of the matter is
column5: the big difference here
column6: Gwen
column7: is they are not prepared to deal with states that sponsor terror. They've got a very limited view about how to use U.S. military forces to defend America.  We heard Senator Kerry say the other night that there ought to be some kind of global test before U.S. troops are deployed preemptively to protect the United States. That's part of a track record that goes back to the 1970s when he ran for Congress the first time and said troops should not be deployed without U.N. approval. Then
column8: in the mid-'80s
column9: he ran on the basis of cutting most of our major defense programs. In 1991
column10: he voted against Desert Storm.  It's a consistent pattern over time of always being on the wrong side of defense issues.  A little tough talk in the midst of a campaign or as part of a presidential debate cannot obscure a record of 30 years of being on the wrong side of defense issues.  And they give absolutely no indication
column11: based on that record
column12: of being wiling to go forward and aggressively pursue the war on terror with a kind of strategy that will work
column13: that will defeat our enemies and will guarantee that the United States doesn't again get attacked by the likes of Al Qaida.

column2: we've never let up on Osama bin Laden from day one. We've actively and aggressively pursued him. We've captured or killed thousands of Al Qaida in various places around the world and especially in Afghanistan. We'll continue to very aggressively pursue him
column3: and I'm confident eventually we'll get him. The key to success in Afghanistan has been
column4: again
column5: to go in and go after the terrorists
column6: which we've done
column7: and also take down the Taliban regime which allowed them to function there
column8: in effect sponsors
column9: if you will
column10: of the Al Qaida organization.  John Edwards
column11: two and a half years ago
column12: six months after we went into Afghanistan announced that it was chaotic
column13: the situation was deteriorating
column14: the warlords were about to take over. Here we are
column15: two and a half years later
column16: we're four days away from a democratic election
column17: the first one in history in Afghanistan. We've got 10 million voters who have registered to vote
column18: nearly half of them women.  That election will put in place a democratically elected government that will take over next December.  We've made enormous progress in Afghanistan
column19: in exactly the right direction
column20: in spite of what John Edwards said two and a half years ago. He just got it wrong.  The fact is
column21: as we go forward in Afghanistan
column22: we will pursue Osama bin Laden and the terrorists as long as necessary. We're standing up Afghan security forces so they can take on responsibility for their own security. We'll keep U.S. forces there -- we have about 16
column23: 000 there today -- as long as necessary
column24: to assist the Afghans in terms of dealing with their security situation. But they're making significant progress. We have President Karzai
column25: who is in power. They have done wonders writing their own constitution for the first time ever. Schools are open. Young girls are going to school. Women are going to vote. Women are even eligible to run for office. This is major
column26: major progress. There will be democracy in Afghanistan
column27: make no doubt about it. Freedom is the best antidote to terror.

column1: Someone did get it wrong. But it wasn't John Kerry and John Edwards. They got it wrong. When we had Osama bin Laden cornered
column2: they left the job to the Afghan warlords. They then diverted their attention from the very people who attacked us
column3: who were at the center of the war on terror
column4: and so Osama bin Laden is still at large. Now
column5: I want to go back to something the vice president said just a minute ago
column6: because these distortions are continuing. He said that -- made mention of this global test. What John Kerry said -- and it's just as clear as day to anybody who was listening -- he said: We will find terrorists where they are and kill them before they ever do harm to the American people
column7: first.  We will keep this country safe. He defended this country as a young man
column8: he will defend this country as president of the United States.  He also said very clearly that he will never give any country veto power over the security of the United States of America.  Now
column9: I know the vice president would like to pretend that wasn't said
column10: and the president would too. But the reality is it was said.  Here's what's actually happened in Afghanistan
column11: regardless of this rosy scenario that they paint on Afghanistan
column12: just like they do with Iraq. What's actually happened is they're now providing 75 percent of the world's opium.  Not only are they providing 75 percent of the world's opium
column13: large-cut parts of the country are under the control of drug lords and warlords. Big parts of the country are still insecure.  And the reality is the part of Afghanistan
column14: eastern Afghanistan
column15: where Osama bin Laden is
column16: is one of the hardest places to control and the most insecure
column17: Gwen.

column1: Twenty years ago we had a similar situation in El Salvador. We had -- guerrilla insurgency controlled roughly a third of the country
column3: 000 people dead
column4: and we held free elections. I was there as an observer on behalf of the Congress. The human drive for freedom
column5: the determination of these people to vote
column6: was unbelievable. And the terrorists would come in and shoot up polling places; as soon as they left
column7: the voters would come back and get in line and would not be denied the right to vote.  And today El Salvador is a whale of a lot better because we held free elections.  The power of that concept is enormous. And it will apply in Afghanistan
column8: and it will apply as well in Iraq.

column1: The vice president just said that we should focus on state sponsors of terrorism. Iran has moved forward with its nuclear weapons program. They're more dangerous today than they were four years ago. North Korea has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program
column2: gone from one to two nuclear weapons to six to eight nuclear weapons. This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran
column3: the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet.  It's a mistake. We should not only not lift them
column4: we should strengthen those sanctions.

column3: first
column4: he said in the same segment -- I don't remember precisely where it was connected with what you just read -- but he said
column5: point blank
column6: ""We will never give anyone a veto over the security of the United States of America."" What he's saying is we're going to go back to the proud tradition of the United States of America and presidents of the United States of America for the last 50 to 75 years.  First
column7: we're going to actually tell the American people the truth. We're going to tell them the truth about what's happening.  We're not going to suggest to them that things are going well in Iraq or anyplace else when
column8: in fact
column9: they're not.  We're going to make sure that the American people know the truth about why we are using force and what the explanation for it is.  And it's not just the American people. We're also going to make sure that we tell the world the truth.  Because the reality is
column10: for America to lead
column11: for America to do what it's done for 50 years before this president and vice president came into office
column12: it is critical that we be credible.  It is critical that they believe that when America takes action
column13: they can trust what we're doing
column14: what we say
column15: what we say at the United Nations
column16: what we say in direct conversations with leaders of the world -- of other countries.  They need to know that the credibility of the United States is always good
column17: because they will not follow us without that.  And unfortunately
column18: we're seeing the consequences of that right now.  It's one of the reasons that we're having so much difficulty getting others involved in the effort in Iraq.  You know
column19: we've taken 90 percent of the coalition casualties. American taxpayers have borne 90 percent of the costs of the effort in Iraq.  And we see the result of there not being a coalition: The first Gulf war cost America $5 billion. We're at $200 billion and counting.  John Kerry will never give up control over the security of the United States of America to any other country. We will not outsource our responsibility to keep this country safe.

column3: the 90 percent figure is just dead wrong. When you include the Iraqi security forces that have suffered casualties
column4: as well as the allies
column5: they've taken almost 50 percent of the casualties in operations in Iraq
column6: which leaves the U.S. with 50 percent
column7: not 90 percent. With respect to the cost
column8: it wasn't $200 billion. You probably weren't there to vote for that. But $120 billion is
column9: in fact
column10: what has been allocated to Iraq. The rest of it's for Afghanistan and the global war on terror.  The allies have stepped forward and agreed to reduce and forgive Iraqi debt to the tune of nearly $80 billion by one estimate. That
column11: plus $14 billion they promised in terms of direct aid
column12: puts the overall allied contribution financially at about $95 billion
column13: not to the $120 billion we've got
column14: but
column15: you know
column16: better than 40 percent. So your facts are just wrong
column17: Senator.  You also have a situation where you talk about credibility.  It's awfully hard to convey a sense of credibility to allies when you voted for the war and then you declared: Wrong war
column18: wrong place
column19: wrong time. You voted for the war
column20: and then you voted against supporting the troops when they needed the equipment
column21: the fuel
column22: the spare parts and the ammunition and the body armor.  You're not credible on Iraq because of the enormous inconsistencies that John Kerry and you have cited time after time after time during the course of the campaign. Whatever the political pressures of the moment requires
column23: that's where you're at. But you've not been consistent
column24: and there's no indication at all that John Kerry has the conviction to successfully carry through on the war on terror.

column1: May I respond briefly? What the vice president has just said is just a complete distortion. The American people saw John Kerry on Thursday night. They don't need the vice president or the president to tell them what they saw.  They saw a man who was strong
column3: who is resolute
column4: who made it very clear that he will do everything that has to be done to find terrorists
column5: to keep the American people safe.  He laid out his plan for success in Iraq
column6: made it clear that we were committed to success in Iraq. We have to be
column7: because we have troops on the ground there and because they have created a haven for terrorists.

column3: would be a lot more credible if there was a record to back it up. There isn't. And you cannot use ""talk tough"" during the course of a 90-minute debate in a presidential campaign to obscure a 30-year record in the United States Senate and
column4: prior to that by John Kerry
column5: who has consistently come down on the wrong side of all the major defense issues that he's faced as a public official.

column1: We heard Senator Kerry say the other night that there ought to be some kind of global test before U.S. troops are deployed preemptively to protect the United States. That's part of a track record that goes back to the 1970s when he ran for Congress the first time and said troops should not be deployed without U.N. approval. Then, in the mid-'80s, he ran on the basis of cutting most of our major defense programs. In 1991, he voted against Desert Storm.  It's a consistent pattern over time of always being on the wrong side of defense issues. column3: 1)	" Gwen
column4: I want to thank you
column5: and I want to thank the folks here at Case Western Reserve for hosting this tonight. It's a very important event
column6: and they've done a superb job of putting it together. It's important to look at all of our developments in Iraq within the broader context of the global war on terror. And
column7: after 9/11
column8: it became clear that we had to do several things to have a successful strategy to win the global war on terror
column9: specifically that we had to go after the terrorists wherever we might find them
column10: that we also had to go after state sponsors of terror
column11: those who might provide sanctuary or safe harbor for terror. And we also then finally had to stand up democracies in their stead afterwards
column12: because that was the only way to guarantee that these states would not again become safe harbors for terror or for the development of deadly weapons.  Concern about Iraq specifically focused on the fact that Saddam Hussein had been
column13: for years
column14: listed on the state sponsor of terror
column15: that they he had established relationships with Abu Nidal
column16: who operated out of Baghdad; he paid $25
column17: 000 to the families of suicide bombers; and he had an established relationship with Al Qaida. Specifically
column18: look at George Tenet
column19: the CIA director's testimony before the Committee on Foreign Relations two years ago when he talked about a 10-year relationship.  The effort that we've mounted with respect to Iraq focused specifically on the possibility that this was the most likely nexus between the terrorists and weapons of mass destruction.  The biggest threat we faced today is the possibility of terrorists smuggling a nuclear weapon or a biological agent into one of our own cities and threatening the lives of hundreds of thousands of Americans.  What we did in Iraq was exactly the right thing to do. If I had it to recommend all over again
column20: I would recommend exactly the same course of action. The world is far safer today because Saddam Hussein is in jail
column21: his government is no longer in power. And we did exactly the right thing.

column3: for moderating this debate. Thank you to the folks of Case Western and all the people in Ohio for having us here.  Mr. Vice President
column4: you are still not being straight with the American people. I mean
column5: the reality you and George Bush continue to tell people
column6: first
column7: that things are going well in Iraq -- the American people don't need us to explain this to them
column8: they see it on their television every single day. We lost more troops in September than we lost in August; lost more in August than we lost in July; lost more in July than we lost in June.  The truth is
column9: our men and women in uniform have been heroic. Our military has done everything they've been asked to do.  And it's not just me that sees the mess in Iraq. There are Republican leaders
column10: like John McCain
column11: like Richard Lugar
column12: like Chuck Hagel
column13: who have said Iraq is a mess and it's getting worse. And when they were asked why
column14: Richard Lugar said because of the incompetence of the administration.  What Paul Bremer said yesterday is they didn't have enough troops to secure the country. They also didn't have a plan to win the peace. They also didn't put the alliances together to make this successful.  We need a fresh start. We need a president who will speed up the training of the Iraqis
column15: get more staff in for doing that. We need to speed up the reconstruction so the Iraqis see some tangible benefit. We need a new president who has the credibility
column16: which John Kerry has
column17: to bring others into this effort.

column1: We've made significant progress in Iraq. We've stood up a new government that's been in power now only 90 days. The notion of additional troops is talked about frequently
column2: but the point of success in Iraq will be reached when we have turned governance over to the Iraqi people; they have been able to establish a democratic government. They're well on their way to doing that. They will have free elections next January for the first time in history. We also are actively
column3: rapidly training Iraqis to take on the security responsibility.  Those two steps are crucial to success in Iraq. They're well in hand
column4: well under way. And I'm confident that
column5: in fact
column6: we'll get the job done.

column2: there is no connection between the attacks of September 11th and Saddam Hussein. The 9/11 Commission has said it. Your own secretary of state has said it. And you've gone around the country suggesting that there is some connection. There is not.  And in fact the CIA is now about to report that the connection between Al Qaida and Saddam Hussein is tenuous at best. And
column3: in fact
column4: the secretary of defense said yesterday that he knows of no hard evidence of the connection.  We need to be straight with the American people.

column1: Here's what it means: It means that Saddam Hussein needed to be confronted. John Kerry and I have consistently said that. That's why we voted for the resolution. But it also means it needed to be done the right way. And doing it the right way meant that we were prepared; that we gave the weapons inspectors time to find out what we now know
column2: that in fact there were no weapons of mass destruction; that we didn't take our eye off the ball
column3: which are Al Qaida
column4: Osama bin Laden
column5: the people who attacked us on September the 11th. Now
column6: remember
column7: we went into Afghanistan
column8: which
column9: by the way
column10: was the right thing to do. That was the right decision. And our military performed terrifically there.  But we had Osama bin Laden cornered at Tora Bora. We had the 10th Mountain Division up in Uzbekistan available. We had the finest military in the world on the ground. And what did we do?  We turned -- this is the man who masterminded the greatest mass murder and terrorist attack in American history. And what did the administration decide to do?  They gave the responsibility of capturing and/or killing Saddam -- I mean Osama bin Laden to Afghan warlords who
column11: just a few weeks before
column12: had been working with Osama bin Laden.  Our point in this is not complicated: We were attacked by Al Qaida and Osama bin Laden.  We went into Afghanistan and very quickly the administration made a decision to divert attention from that and instead began to plan for the invasion of Iraq.  And these connections -- I want the American people to hear this very clearly. Listen carefully to what the vice president is saying. Because there is no connection between Saddam Hussein and the attacks of September 11th -- period.  The 9/11 Commission has said that's true. Colin Powell has said it's true. But the vice president keeps suggesting that there is. There is not. And
column13: in fact
column14: any connection with Al Qaida is tenuous at best.

column1: The senator has got his facts wrong. I have not suggested there's a connection between Iraq and 9/11
column2: but there's clearly an established Iraqi track record with terror. And the point is that that's the place where you're most likely to see the terrorists come together with weapons of mass destruction
column3: the deadly technologies that Saddam Hussein had developed and used over the years.  Now
column4: the fact of the matter is
column5: the big difference here
column6: Gwen
column7: is they are not prepared to deal with states that sponsor terror. They've got a very limited view about how to use U.S. military forces to defend America.  We heard Senator Kerry say the other night that there ought to be some kind of global test before U.S. troops are deployed preemptively to protect the United States. That's part of a track record that goes back to the 1970s when he ran for Congress the first time and said troops should not be deployed without U.N. approval. Then
column8: in the mid-'80s
column9: he ran on the basis of cutting most of our major defense programs. In 1991
column10: he voted against Desert Storm.  It's a consistent pattern over time of always being on the wrong side of defense issues.  A little tough talk in the midst of a campaign or as part of a presidential debate cannot obscure a record of 30 years of being on the wrong side of defense issues.  And they give absolutely no indication
column11: based on that record
column12: of being wiling to go forward and aggressively pursue the war on terror with a kind of strategy that will work
column13: that will defeat our enemies and will guarantee that the United States doesn't again get attacked by the likes of Al Qaida.

column2: we've never let up on Osama bin Laden from day one. We've actively and aggressively pursued him. We've captured or killed thousands of Al Qaida in various places around the world and especially in Afghanistan. We'll continue to very aggressively pursue him
column3: and I'm confident eventually we'll get him. The key to success in Afghanistan has been
column4: again
column5: to go in and go after the terrorists
column6: which we've done
column7: and also take down the Taliban regime which allowed them to function there
column8: in effect sponsors
column9: if you will
column10: of the Al Qaida organization.  John Edwards
column11: two and a half years ago
column12: six months after we went into Afghanistan announced that it was chaotic
column13: the situation was deteriorating
column14: the warlords were about to take over. Here we are
column15: two and a half years later
column16: we're four days away from a democratic election
column17: the first one in history in Afghanistan. We've got 10 million voters who have registered to vote
column18: nearly half of them women.  That election will put in place a democratically elected government that will take over next December.  We've made enormous progress in Afghanistan
column19: in exactly the right direction
column20: in spite of what John Edwards said two and a half years ago. He just got it wrong.  The fact is
column21: as we go forward in Afghanistan
column22: we will pursue Osama bin Laden and the terrorists as long as necessary. We're standing up Afghan security forces so they can take on responsibility for their own security. We'll keep U.S. forces there -- we have about 16
column23: 000 there today -- as long as necessary
column24: to assist the Afghans in terms of dealing with their security situation. But they're making significant progress. We have President Karzai
column25: who is in power. They have done wonders writing their own constitution for the first time ever. Schools are open. Young girls are going to school. Women are going to vote. Women are even eligible to run for office. This is major
column26: major progress. There will be democracy in Afghanistan
column27: make no doubt about it. Freedom is the best antidote to terror.

column1: Someone did get it wrong. But it wasn't John Kerry and John Edwards. They got it wrong. When we had Osama bin Laden cornered
column2: they left the job to the Afghan warlords. They then diverted their attention from the very people who attacked us
column3: who were at the center of the war on terror
column4: and so Osama bin Laden is still at large. Now
column5: I want to go back to something the vice president said just a minute ago
column6: because these distortions are continuing. He said that -- made mention of this global test. What John Kerry said -- and it's just as clear as day to anybody who was listening -- he said: We will find terrorists where they are and kill them before they ever do harm to the American people
column7: first.  We will keep this country safe. He defended this country as a young man
column8: he will defend this country as president of the United States.  He also said very clearly that he will never give any country veto power over the security of the United States of America.  Now
column9: I know the vice president would like to pretend that wasn't said
column10: and the president would too. But the reality is it was said.  Here's what's actually happened in Afghanistan
column11: regardless of this rosy scenario that they paint on Afghanistan
column12: just like they do with Iraq. What's actually happened is they're now providing 75 percent of the world's opium.  Not only are they providing 75 percent of the world's opium
column13: large-cut parts of the country are under the control of drug lords and warlords. Big parts of the country are still insecure.  And the reality is the part of Afghanistan
column14: eastern Afghanistan
column15: where Osama bin Laden is
column16: is one of the hardest places to control and the most insecure
column17: Gwen.

column1: Twenty years ago we had a similar situation in El Salvador. We had -- guerrilla insurgency controlled roughly a third of the country
column3: 000 people dead
column4: and we held free elections. I was there as an observer on behalf of the Congress. The human drive for freedom
column5: the determination of these people to vote
column6: was unbelievable. And the terrorists would come in and shoot up polling places; as soon as they left
column7: the voters would come back and get in line and would not be denied the right to vote.  And today El Salvador is a whale of a lot better because we held free elections.  The power of that concept is enormous. And it will apply in Afghanistan
column8: and it will apply as well in Iraq.

column1: The vice president just said that we should focus on state sponsors of terrorism. Iran has moved forward with its nuclear weapons program. They're more dangerous today than they were four years ago. North Korea has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program
column2: gone from one to two nuclear weapons to six to eight nuclear weapons. This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran
column3: the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet.  It's a mistake. We should not only not lift them
column4: we should strengthen those sanctions.

column3: first
column4: he said in the same segment -- I don't remember precisely where it was connected with what you just read -- but he said
column5: point blank
column6: ""We will never give anyone a veto over the security of the United States of America."" What he's saying is we're going to go back to the proud tradition of the United States of America and presidents of the United States of America for the last 50 to 75 years.  First
column7: we're going to actually tell the American people the truth. We're going to tell them the truth about what's happening.  We're not going to suggest to them that things are going well in Iraq or anyplace else when
column8: in fact
column9: they're not.  We're going to make sure that the American people know the truth about why we are using force and what the explanation for it is.  And it's not just the American people. We're also going to make sure that we tell the world the truth.  Because the reality is
column10: for America to lead
column11: for America to do what it's done for 50 years before this president and vice president came into office
column12: it is critical that we be credible.  It is critical that they believe that when America takes action
column13: they can trust what we're doing
column14: what we say
column15: what we say at the United Nations
column16: what we say in direct conversations with leaders of the world -- of other countries.  They need to know that the credibility of the United States is always good
column17: because they will not follow us without that.  And unfortunately
column18: we're seeing the consequences of that right now.  It's one of the reasons that we're having so much difficulty getting others involved in the effort in Iraq.  You know
column19: we've taken 90 percent of the coalition casualties. American taxpayers have borne 90 percent of the costs of the effort in Iraq.  And we see the result of there not being a coalition: The first Gulf war cost America $5 billion. We're at $200 billion and counting.  John Kerry will never give up control over the security of the United States of America to any other country. We will not outsource our responsibility to keep this country safe.

column3: the 90 percent figure is just dead wrong. When you include the Iraqi security forces that have suffered casualties
column4: as well as the allies
column5: they've taken almost 50 percent of the casualties in operations in Iraq
column6: which leaves the U.S. with 50 percent
column7: not 90 percent. With respect to the cost
column8: it wasn't $200 billion. You probably weren't there to vote for that. But $120 billion is
column9: in fact
column10: what has been allocated to Iraq. The rest of it's for Afghanistan and the global war on terror.  The allies have stepped forward and agreed to reduce and forgive Iraqi debt to the tune of nearly $80 billion by one estimate. That
column11: plus $14 billion they promised in terms of direct aid
column12: puts the overall allied contribution financially at about $95 billion
column13: not to the $120 billion we've got
column14: but
column15: you know
column16: better than 40 percent. So your facts are just wrong
column17: Senator.  You also have a situation where you talk about credibility.  It's awfully hard to convey a sense of credibility to allies when you voted for the war and then you declared: Wrong war
column18: wrong place
column19: wrong time. You voted for the war
column20: and then you voted against supporting the troops when they needed the equipment
column21: the fuel
column22: the spare parts and the ammunition and the body armor.  You're not credible on Iraq because of the enormous inconsistencies that John Kerry and you have cited time after time after time during the course of the campaign. Whatever the political pressures of the moment requires
column23: that's where you're at. But you've not been consistent
column24: and there's no indication at all that John Kerry has the conviction to successfully carry through on the war on terror.

column1: May I respond briefly? What the vice president has just said is just a complete distortion. The American people saw John Kerry on Thursday night. They don't need the vice president or the president to tell them what they saw.  They saw a man who was strong
column3: who is resolute
column4: who made it very clear that he will do everything that has to be done to find terrorists
column5: to keep the American people safe.  He laid out his plan for success in Iraq
column6: made it clear that we were committed to success in Iraq. We have to be

column1: We heard Senator Kerry say the other night that there ought to be some kind of global test before U.S. troops are deployed preemptively to protect the United States. That's part of a track record that goes back to the 1970s when he ran for Congress the first time and said troops should not be deployed without U.N. approval. Then, in the mid-'80s, he ran on the basis of cutting most of our major defense programs. In 1991, he voted against Desert Storm.  It's a consistent pattern over time of always being on the wrong side of defense issues. a very important event, and theyve done a superb job of putting it together', 'Its important to look at all of our developments in Iraq within the broader context of the global war on terror', 'And, after 9/11, it became clear that we had to do several things to have a successful strategy to win the global war on terror, specifically that we had to go after the terrorists wherever we might find column3: 1)	" Gwen
column4: I want to thank you
column5: and I want to thank the folks here at Case Western Reserve for hosting this tonight. It's a very important event
column6: and they've done a superb job of putting it together. It's important to look at all of our developments in Iraq within the broader context of the global war on terror. And
column7: after 9/11
column8: it became clear that we had to do several things to have a successful strategy to win the global war on terror
column9: specifically that we had to go after the terrorists wherever we might find them
column10: that we also had to go after state sponsors of terror
column11: those who might provide sanctuary or safe harbor for terror. And we also then finally had to stand up democracies in their stead afterwards
column12: because that was the only way to guarantee that these states would not again become safe harbors for terror or for the development of deadly weapons.  Concern about Iraq specifically focused on the fact that Saddam Hussein had been
column13: for years
column14: listed on the state sponsor of terror
column15: that they he had established relationships with Abu Nidal
column16: who operated out of Baghdad; he paid $25
column17: 000 to the families of suicide bombers; and he had an established relationship with Al Qaida. Specifically
column18: look at George Tenet
column19: the CIA director's testimony before the Committee on Foreign Relations two years ago when he talked about a 10-year relationship.  The effort that we've mounted with respect to Iraq focused specifically on the possibility that this was the most likely nexus between the terrorists and weapons of mass destruction.  The biggest threat we faced today is the possibility of terrorists smuggling a nuclear weapon or a biological agent into one of our own cities and threatening the lives of hundreds of thousands of Americans.  What we did in Iraq was exactly the right thing to do. If I had it to recommend all over again
column20: I would recommend exactly the same course of action. The world is far safer today because Saddam Hussein is in jail
column21: his government is no longer in power. And we did exactly the right thing.

column3: for moderating this debate. Thank you to the folks of Case Western and all the people in Ohio for having us here.  Mr. Vice President
column4: you are still not being straight with the American people. I mean
column5: the reality you and George Bush continue to tell people
column6: first
column7: that things are going well in Iraq -- the American people don't need us to explain this to them
column8: they see it on their television every single day. We lost more troops in September than we lost in August; lost more in August than we lost in July; lost more in July than we lost in June.  The truth is
column9: our men and women in uniform have been heroic. Our military has done everything they've been asked to do.  And it's not just me that sees the mess in Iraq. There are Republican leaders
column10: like John McCain
column11: like Richard Lugar
column12: like Chuck Hagel
column13: who have said Iraq is a mess and it's getting worse. And when they were asked why
column14: Richard Lugar said because of the incompetence of the administration.  What Paul Bremer said yesterday is they didn't have enough troops to secure the country. They also didn't have a plan to win the peace. They also didn't put the alliances together to make this successful.  We need a fresh start. We need a president who will speed up the training of the Iraqis
column15: get more staff in for doing that. We need to speed up the reconstruction so the Iraqis see some tangible benefit. We need a new president who has the credibility
column16: which John Kerry has
column17: to bring others into this effort.

column1: We've made significant progress in Iraq. We've stood up a new government that's been in power now only 90 days. The notion of additional troops is talked about frequently
column2: but the point of success in Iraq will be reached when we have turned governance over to the Iraqi people; they have been able to establish a democratic government. They're well on their way to doing that. They will have free elections next January for the first time in history. We also are actively
column3: rapidly training Iraqis to take on the security responsibility.  Those two steps are crucial to success in Iraq. They're well in hand
column4: well under way. And I'm confident that
column5: in fact
column6: we'll get the job done.

column2: there is no connection between the attacks of September 11th and Saddam Hussein. The 9/11 Commission has said it. Your own secretary of state has said it. And you've gone around the country suggesting that there is some connection. There is not.  And in fact the CIA is now about to report that the connection between Al Qaida and Saddam Hussein is tenuous at best. And
column3: in fact
column4: the secretary of defense said yesterday that he knows of no hard evidence of the connection.  We need to be straight with the American people.

column1: Here's what it means: It means that Saddam Hussein needed to be confronted. John Kerry and I have consistently said that. That's why we voted for the resolution. But it also means it needed to be done the right way. And doing it the right way meant that we were prepared; that we gave the weapons inspectors time to find out what we now know
column2: that in fact there were no weapons of mass destruction; that we didn't take our eye off the ball
column3: which are Al Qaida
column4: Osama bin Laden
column5: the people who attacked us on September the 11th. Now
column6: remember
column7: we went into Afghanistan
column8: which
column9: by the way
column10: was the right thing to do. That was the right decision. And our military performed terrifically there.  But we had Osama bin Laden cornered at Tora Bora. We had the 10th Mountain Division up in Uzbekistan available. We had the finest military in the world on the ground. And what did we do?  We turned -- this is the man who masterminded the greatest mass murder and terrorist attack in American history. And what did the administration decide to do?  They gave the responsibility of capturing and/or killing Saddam -- I mean Osama bin Laden to Afghan warlords who
column11: just a few weeks before
column12: had been working with Osama bin Laden.  Our point in this is not complicated: We were attacked by Al Qaida and Osama bin Laden.  We went into Afghanistan and very quickly the administration made a decision to divert attention from that and instead began to plan for the invasion of Iraq.  And these connections -- I want the American people to hear this very clearly. Listen carefully to what the vice president is saying. Because there is no connection between Saddam Hussein and the attacks of September 11th -- period.  The 9/11 Commission has said that's true. Colin Powell has said it's true. But the vice president keeps suggesting that there is. There is not. And
column13: in fact
column14: any connection with Al Qaida is tenuous at best.

column1: The senator has got his facts wrong. I have not suggested there's a connection between Iraq and 9/11
column2: but there's clearly an established Iraqi track record with terror. And the point is that that's the place where you're most likely to see the terrorists come together with weapons of mass destruction
column3: the deadly technologies that Saddam Hussein had developed and used over the years.  Now
column4: the fact of the matter is
column5: the big difference here
column6: Gwen
column7: is they are not prepared to deal with states that sponsor terror. They've got a very limited view about how to use U.S. military forces to defend America.  We heard Senator Kerry say the other night that there ought to be some kind of global test before U.S. troops are deployed preemptively to protect the United States. That's part of a track record that goes back to the 1970s when he ran for Congress the first time and said troops should not be deployed without U.N. approval. Then
column8: in the mid-'80s
column9: he ran on the basis of cutting most of our major defense programs. In 1991
column10: he voted against Desert Storm.  It's a consistent pattern over time of always being on the wrong side of defense issues.  A little tough talk in the midst of a campaign or as part of a presidential debate cannot obscure a record of 30 years of being on the wrong side of defense issues.  And they give absolutely no indication
column11: based on that record
column12: of being wiling to go forward and aggressively pursue the war on terror with a kind of strategy that will work
column13: that will defeat our enemies and will guarantee that the United States doesn't again get attacked by the likes of Al Qaida.

column2: we've never let up on Osama bin Laden from day one. We've actively and aggressively pursued him. We've captured or killed thousands of Al Qaida in various places around the world and especially in Afghanistan. We'll continue to very aggressively pursue him
column3: and I'm confident eventually we'll get him. The key to success in Afghanistan has been
column4: again
column5: to go in and go after the terrorists
column6: which we've done
column7: and also take down the Taliban regime which allowed them to function there
column8: in effect sponsors
column9: if you will
column10: of the Al Qaida organization.  John Edwards
column11: two and a half years ago
column12: six months after we went into Afghanistan announced that it was chaotic
column13: the situation was deteriorating
column14: the warlords were about to take over. Here we are
column15: two and a half years later
column16: we're four days away from a democratic election
column17: the first one in history in Afghanistan. We've got 10 million voters who have registered to vote
column18: nearly half of them women.  That election will put in place a democratically elected government that will take over next December.  We've made enormous progress in Afghanistan
column19: in exactly the right direction
column20: in spite of what John Edwards said two and a half years ago. He just got it wrong.  The fact is
column21: as we go forward in Afghanistan
column22: we will pursue Osama bin Laden and the terrorists as long as necessary. We're standing up Afghan security forces so they can take on responsibility for their own security. We'll keep U.S. forces there -- we have about 16
column23: 000 there today -- as long as necessary
column24: to assist the Afghans in terms of dealing with their security situation. But they're making significant progress. We have President Karzai
column25: who is in power. They have done wonders writing their own constitution for the first time ever. Schools are open. Young girls are going to school. Women are going to vote. Women are even eligible to run for office. This is major
column26: major progress. There will be democracy in Afghanistan
column27: make no doubt about it. Freedom is the best antidote to terror.

column1: Someone did get it wrong. But it wasn't John Kerry and John Edwards. They got it wrong. When we had Osama bin Laden cornered
column2: they left the job to the Afghan warlords. They then diverted their attention from the very people who attacked us
column3: who were at the center of the war on terror
column4: and so Osama bin Laden is still at large. Now
column5: I want to go back to something the vice president said just a minute ago
column6: because these distortions are continuing. He said that -- made mention of this global test. What John Kerry said -- and it's just as clear as day to anybody who was listening -- he said: We will find terrorists where they are and kill them before they ever do harm to the American people
column7: first.  We will keep this country safe. He defended this country as a young man
column8: he will defend this country as president of the United States.  He also said very clearly that he will never give any country veto power over the security of the United States of America.  Now
column9: I know the vice president would like to pretend that wasn't said
column10: and the president would too. But the reality is it was said.  Here's what's actually happened in Afghanistan
column11: regardless of this rosy scenario that they paint on Afghanistan
column12: just like they do with Iraq. What's actually happened is they're now providing 75 percent of the world's opium.  Not only are they providing 75 percent of the world's opium
column13: large-cut parts of the country are under the control of drug lords and warlords. Big parts of the country are still insecure.  And the reality is the part of Afghanistan
column14: eastern Afghanistan
column15: where Osama bin Laden is
column16: is one of the hardest places to control and the most insecure
column17: Gwen.

column1: Twenty years ago we had a similar situation in El Salvador. We had -- guerrilla insurgency controlled roughly a third of the country
column3: 000 people dead
column4: and we held free elections. I was there as an observer on behalf of the Congress. The human drive for freedom
column5: the determination of these people to vote
column6: was unbelievable. And the terrorists would come in and shoot up polling places; as soon as they left
column7: the voters would come back and get in line and would not be denied the right to vote.  And today El Salvador is a whale of a lot better because we held free elections.  The power of that concept is enormous. And it will apply in Afghanistan
column8: and it will apply as well in Iraq.

column1: The vice president just said that we should focus on state sponsors of terrorism. Iran has moved forward with its nuclear weapons program. They're more dangerous today than they were four years ago. North Korea has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program
column2: gone from one to two nuclear weapons to six to eight nuclear weapons. This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran
column3: the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet.  It's a mistake. We should not only not lift them
column4: we should strengthen those sanctions.

column3: first
column4: he said in the same segment -- I don't remember precisely where it was connected with what you just read -- but he said
column5: point blank
column6: ""We will never give anyone a veto over the security of the United States of America."" What he's saying is we're going to go back to the proud tradition of the United States of America and presidents of the United States of America for the last 50 to 75 years.  First
column7: we're going to actually tell the American people the truth. We're going to tell them the truth about what's happening.  We're not going to suggest to them that things are going well in Iraq or anyplace else when
column8: in fact
column9: they're not.  We're going to make sure that the American people know the truth about why we are using force and what the explanation for it is.  And it's not just the American people. We're also going to make sure that we tell the world the truth.  Because the reality is
column10: for America to lead
column11: for America to do what it's done for 50 years before this president and vice president came into office
column12: it is critical that we be credible.  It is critical that they believe that when America takes action
column13: they can trust what we're doing
column14: what we say
column15: what we say at the United Nations
column16: what we say in direct conversations with leaders of the world -- of other countries.  They need to know that the credibility of the United States is always good
column17: because they will not follow us without that.  And unfortunately
column18: we're seeing the consequences of that right now.  It's one of the reasons that we're having so much difficulty getting others involved in the effort in Iraq.  You know
column19: we've taken 90 percent of the coalition casualties. American taxpayers have borne 90 percent of the costs of the effort in Iraq.  And we see the result of there not being a coalition: The first Gulf war cost America $5 billion. We're at $200 billion and counting.  John Kerry will never give up control over the security of the United States of America to any other country. We will not outsource our responsibility to keep this country safe.

column3: the 90 percent figure is just dead wrong. When you include the Iraqi security forces that have suffered casualties
column4: as well as the allies
column5: they've taken almost 50 percent of the casualties in operations in Iraq
column6: which leaves the U.S. with 50 percent
column7: not 90 percent. With respect to the cost
column8: it wasn't $200 billion. You probably weren't there to vote for that. But $120 billion is
column9: in fact
column10: what has been allocated to Iraq. The rest of it's for Afghanistan and the global war on terror.  The allies have stepped forward and agreed to reduce and forgive Iraqi debt to the tune of nearly $80 billion by one estimate. That
column11: plus $14 billion they promised in terms of direct aid
column12: puts the overall allied contribution financially at about $95 billion
column13: not to the $120 billion we've got
column14: but
column15: you know
column16: better than 40 percent. So your facts are just wrong
column17: Senator.  You also have a situation where you talk about credibility.  It's awfully hard to convey a sense of credibility to allies when you voted for the war and then you declared: Wrong war
column18: wrong place
column19: wrong time. You voted for the war
column20: and then you voted against supporting the troops when they needed the equipment
column21: the fuel
column22: the spare parts and the ammunition and the body armor.  You're not credible on Iraq because of the enormous inconsistencies that John Kerry and you have cited time after time after time during the course of the campaign. Whatever the political pressures of the moment requires
column23: that's where you're at. But you've not been consistent
column24: and there's no indication at all that John Kerry has the conviction to successfully carry through on the war on terror.

column1: May I respond briefly? What the vice president has just said is just a complete distortion. The American people saw John Kerry on Thursday night. They don't need the vice president or the president to tell them what they saw.  They saw a man who was strong
column3: who is resolute
column4: who made it very clear that he will do everything that has to be done to find terrorists
column5: to keep the American people safe.  He laid out his plan for success in Iraq
column6: made it clear that we were committed to success in Iraq. We have to be
column7: because we have troops on the ground there and because they have created a haven for terrorists.

column3: would be a lot more credible if there was a record to back it up. There isn't. And you cannot use ""talk tough"" during the course of a 90-minute debate in a presidential campaign to obscure a 30-year record in the United States Senate and
column4: prior to that by John Kerry
column5: who has consistently come down on the wrong side of all the major defense issues that he's faced as a public official.

Then, in the mid-'80s, he ran on the basis of cutting most of our major defense programs. In 1991, he voted against Desert Storm.  It's a consistent pattern over time of always being on the wrong side of defense issues.
