column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it

column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort. column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him
column4: we'll -- I'll stop.

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him
column4: we'll -- I'll stop.

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him
column4: we'll -- I'll stop.

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him
column4: we'll -- I'll stop.

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show

column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off

Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show

column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
