column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him
column4: we'll -- I'll stop.

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students

column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it

column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him
column4: we'll -- I'll stop.

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him
column4: we'll -- I'll stop.

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: let me say that John Kerry has -- I can use his name now?

column3: been completely consistent about Iraq. We've made very clear from the beginning -- and not an afterthought; we said it at the time -- that we had to confront Saddam Hussein and that we had to have a coalition and a plan to be successful. And the vice president didn't say much about it in your earlier question
column4: but Paul Bremer has now made clear that they didn't have enough troops and they didn't have a plan.  And the American people are seeing the results of that every single day
column5: in spite of the proud and courageous service of our men and women in uniform.  Now
column6: flip-flops: They should know something about flip-flops. They've seen a lot of it during their administration.  They were first against the 9/11 Commission; then they were for it. They were for a department of homeland security -- I mean
column7: they were against the Department of Homeland Security; then they were for it.  They said they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus when they came into office aside to protect Social Security; then they changed their minds. They said that they supported the troops; and then while our troops were on the ground in Iraq and Afghanistan
column8: they went to the Congress and lobbied to have their combat pay cut.  They said that they were going to do something about health care in this country. And they've done something: They've made it worse.  They said that they were going to fund their No Child Left Behind; $27 billion short today.  Over and over
column9: this administration has said one thing and done another.  This president said -- I listened to him the other night at his 2000 debate saying: I'm for a national patients' bill of rights.  I know something about this. John McCain and Senator Kennedy and I wrote it
column10: got it passed in the Senate. We don't have a patients' bill of rights because of one man today
column11: the president of the United States. They've gone back and forth.

column3: I can think of a lot of words to describe Senator Kerry's position on Iraq; ""consistent"" is not one of them. I think if you look at the record from voting for sending the troops then voting against the resources they needed when they got there
column4: then saying I actually voted for the $87 billion before I voted against it
column5: saying in response to a question knowing everything I know now
column6: yes
column7: I would have cast exactly the same vote and then shortly after that saying wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: consistency doesn't come to mind as I consider that record.  The question of troops is an interesting and important one. We have looked to our commanders on the ground in Iraq for guidance on what they think they need. If they need more troops
column11: they'll ask us.  But the key here is not to try to solve the problems in Iraq by putting in more American troops. The key is to get the Iraqis to take on the responsibility for their own security. That's exactly what we're doing.  If you put American troops in there in larger number and don't get the Iraqis into the fight
column12: you'll postpone the day when you can in fact bring our boys home. It's vital that we deal with any need for additional troops by putting Iraqis into the effort.  Forty-nine percent increase in funding for elementary and secondary education under No Child Left Behind; that's a lot of money even by Massachusetts' standards.

column2: but they didn't fund the mandates that they put on the schools all over this country. That's the reason 800 teachers -- one of the reasons -- 800 teachers have been laid off
column3: right here in Cleveland. One-third of our public schools are failing under this administration. Half of African-Americans are dropping out of high school. Half of Hispanic-American are dropping out of high school. John and I have -- and I don't have the time now -- but we have a clear plan to improve our public schools that starts with getting our best teachers into the schools where we need them the most by creating incentives for them to go there.

they were for it; now they're against it. They voted for it; now they're opposed to it. We are making significant progress there. We are closing the achievement gap. The results coming in from a number of studies show
column4: without question
column5: that on math and reading
column6: that in fact our minority students
column7: our Hispanic and African-American students are doing better
column8: and that gap between them and the majority population is
column9: in fact
column10: closing.  So we are doing exactly the right thing. They're the ones who have been for the Patriot Act and against it
column11: for No Child Left Behind and then against it.

column3: 30 seconds
column4: please
column5: yes. We are for accountability
column6: and we are for high standards. John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.  But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?

column3: if you feel like you need to go to him
column4: we'll -- I'll stop.

column2: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column3: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column4: for example
column5: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day. We had some success early on
column6: I think
column7: in No Child Left Behind
column8: when we
column9: in fact
column10: had broad
column11: bipartisan support.  We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column12: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis. Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side. All I know is to continue to try to work it.  It's a disappointment
column13: in a sense
column14: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column15: when
column16: in fact
column17: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column18: like Tom Foley
column19: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House. One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column20: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.  We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days. I'm not sure exactly why. I think
column21: in part
column22: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.  And the Senate
column23: of course
column24: has been very evenly divided
column26: then 51-49
column27: then 49-51 the other way.  We'll keep working at it.  I think it's important for us to try. I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible. We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller. So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.  And hopefully in a second term
column28: we'll see an improvement along those lines.

column1: Thank you. The president said that he would unite this country
column3: not a divider.  Have you ever seen America more divided? Have you ever seen Washington more divided?  The reality is it is not an accident. It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America. We can do better than that in this country.  Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column4: because we touched it
column5: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.  I mean
column6: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.  We need to talk about what we will do that they haven't done.  First
column7: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans. We're going to cover all kids.  Not only that
column8: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.  And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column9: save them up to $1
column10: 000 a year
column11: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.  And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.  They've blocked allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada. We're going to allow it.  They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors. We're going to allow it.  We're also going to stand up to the drug companies and do something about these drug company ads on television which are out of control.

column3: it's hard to know where to start. The fact of the matter is
column4: the most important and significant change in health care in the last several years was the Medicare reform bill this year. It's the most sweeping change in 40 years.  Medicare used to pay for heart bypass surgery but didn't pay for the prescription drugs that might allow you to avoid it.  The fact is that when that came up
column5: Senator Kerry and Senator Edwards voted against it. It'll provide prescription drug benefits to 40 million senior citizens. It's a very
column6: very significant piece of legislation.

column1: They had a choice on allowing prescription drugs into this country from Canada
column2: of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies. They had a choice on negotiating discounts in the Medicare prescription drug bill of being with the American people or with the drug companies. They were with the drug companies.  They had a choice on the patients' bill of rights
column3: allowing people to make their own health care decisions and not having insurance companies make them
column4: be with the American people
column5: be with the big insurance companies.  They're with the insurance companies.  John Kerry and I will always fight for the American people.

column87: and we are for high standards.'
column88: 'John and I voted for No Child Left Behind because we thought that accountability and standards were the right thing to do.'
column89: 'But they make -- did you figure out you were wrong?.'
column90: ""Well
column91: in fairness
column92: if you feel like you need to go to him
column93: we'll -- I'll stop.""
column94: ""Well
column95: I must say it's one of the disappointments of the last four years
column96: is that we've not been able to do what the president did in Texas
column98: when he was able to reach across the aisle and bring Democrats along on major issues of the day.""
column100: I think
column106: 'We had a lot of support for the Patriot Act
column107: when we passed that on a bipartisan basis.'
column108: ""Now we're seeing objection to that by the other side.""
column109: 'All I know is to continue to try to work it.'
column110: ""It's a disappointment
column112: that I remember from my earlier service when things worked much differently
column113: when
column115: some of my best friends in the Congress were people I worked with
column117: who was a majority leader and later speaker of the House.""
column118: 'One of my strongest allies in Congress when I was secretary of defense was Jack Murtha
column119: a Democrat who is chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee.'
column120: 'We used to be able to do more together on a bipartisan basis than seems possible these days.'
column122: 'I think
column124: it may be the change in the majority-minority status in the Senate has been difficult for both sides to adjust to.'
column129: then 51-49
column132: ""I think it's important for us to try.""
column133: 'I believe that it is essential for us to do everything we can to garner as much support from the other side of the aisle as possible.'
column134: ""We've had support -- we had our keynote address at our convention was delivered by Zell Miller.""
column135: 'So there are some Democrats who agree with our approach.'
column137: we'll see an improvement along those lines.""
column139: 'The president said that he would unite this country
column140: that he was a uniter
column141: not a divider.'
column142: 'Have you ever seen America more divided?'
column143: 'Have you ever seen Washington more divided?'
column144: 'The reality is it is not an accident.'
column145: ""It's the direct result of the choices they've made and their efforts that have created division in America.""
column146: 'We can do better than that in this country.'
column147: 'Now I want to go back to the whole issue of health care
column149: but I think the American people deserve to know what we would do different.'
column151: 5 million people losing their health care -- everyone who's watching this knows health insurance premiums are through the roof.""

column153: ""First
column154: we're going to make the same health care that's available to members of Congress available to all Americans.""
column157: we're going to bring down costs by pooling the catastrophic costs so we bring down premiums.""
column158: ""And we're going to give tax breaks directly to families
column161: and to businesses -- the vice president talked about that a few minutes ago -- so that they can provide health care to their employees.""
column162: ""And we're also going to finally do something about the cost of prescription drugs.""

column165: 'They would not allow the government to use its negotiating power to get discounts for seniors.'

column3: 2)	" I'm saying specifically that I don't believe he has the qualities we need in a commander in chief because I don't think
column4: based on his record
column5: that he would pursue the kind of aggressive policies that need to be pursued if we're going to defeat these terrorists. We need to battle them overseas so we don't have to battle them here at home. I'm not challenging John Kerry's patriotism. I said in my acceptance speech in New York City at the Republican convention that we respected his service in Vietnam
column6: and I got applause for that.  We've never criticized his patriotism. What we've questioned is his judgment.  And his judgment's flawed
column7: and the record's there for anybody who wants to look at it.  In 1984
column8: when he ran for the Senate he opposed
column9: or called for the elimination of a great many major weapons systems that were crucial to winning the Cold War and are important today to our overall forces.  When Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait and occupied it in 1990 and '91
column10: he stood up on the floor of the Senate and voted against going in to liberate Kuwait and push Saddam Hussein back to Iraq.  The problem we have is that
column11: if you look at his record
column12: he doesn't display the qualities of somebody who has conviction.  And with respect to this particular operation
column13: we've seen a situation in which
column14: first
column15: they voted to commit the troops
column16: to send them to war
column17: John Edwards and John Kerry
column18: then they came back and when the question was whether or not you provide them with the resources they needed -- body armor
column19: spare parts
column20: ammunition -- they voted against it.  I couldn't figure out why that happened initially. And then I looked and figured out that what was happening was Howard Dean was making major progress in the Democratic primaries
column21: running away with the primaries based on an anti-war record. So they
column22: in effect
column23: decided they would cast an anti-war vote and they voted against the troops.  Now if they couldn't stand up to the pressures that Howard Dean represented
column24: how can we expect them to stand up to Al Qaida?

column1: Thank you. One thing that's very clear is that a long resume does not equal good judgment. I mean
column2: we've seen over and over and over the misjudgments made by this administration.  I want to go back to what the vice president just said
column3: because it's a continuation of the things he's been doing
column4: unfortunately
column5: on the campaign trail; it's a continuation of what he began his first answer with tonight.  John Kerry has voted for the biggest military appropriations bill in the country's history. John Kerry has voted for the biggest intelligence appropriations in the country's history.  This vice president
column6: when he was secretary of defense
column7: cut over 80 weapons systems
column8: including the very ones he's criticizing John Kerry for voting against. These are weapons systems
column9: a big chunk of which
column10: the vice president himself suggested we get rid of after the Cold War.  The reality is that John Kerry has consistently supported the very men that he served with in Vietnam and led.  On the $87 billion
column11: it was clear at the time of that vote that they had no plan to win the peace. We're seeing the consequences of that everyday on the ground right now.  We stood up and said: For our troops
column12: we must have a plan to win the peace.  We also thought it was wrong to have a $20 billion fund out of which $7.5 billion was going to go to a no-bid contract for Halliburton
column13: the vice president's former company.  It was wrong then. It's wrong now.

column3: I think the record speaks for itself. These are two individuals who have been for the war when the headlines were good and against it when their poll ratings were bad. We have not seen the kind of consistency that a commander in chief has to have in order to be a leader in wartime and in order to be able to see the strategy through to victory.  If we want to win the war on terror
column4: it seems to me it's pretty clear the choice is George Bush
column5: not John Kerry.

column1: John Kerry has been absolutely clear and consistent from the beginning that we must stay focused on the people who attacked us; that Saddam Hussein was a threat that needed to be addressed directly; that the weapons inspectors needed to have time to do their job. Had they had time to do their job
column2: they would have discovered what we now know
column3: that in fact Saddam Hussein had no weapons
column4: that in fact Saddam Hussein has no connection with 9/11
column5: that in fact Saddam Hussein has little or no connection with Al Qaida.

column2: let's start with what we know. What we know is that the president and the vice president have not done the work to build the coalition that we need -- dramatically different than the first Gulf War. We know that they haven't done it
column3: and we know they can't do it. They didn't
column4: by the way
column5: just reject the allies going into lead- up to the war. They also rejected them in the effort to do the reconstruction in Iraq
column6: and that has consequences.  What we believe is
column7: as part of our entire plan for Iraq -- and we have a plan for Iraq.  They have a plan for Iraq too: more of the same.  We have a plan for success. And that plan includes speeding up the training of the military. We have less than half of the staff that we need there to complete that training.  Second
column8: make sure that the reconstruction is sped up in a way that the Iraqis see some tangible benefit for what's happening.  And by the way
column9: if we need to
column10: we can take Iraqis out of Iraq to train them. It is not secure enough. It's so dangerous on the ground that they can't be trained there. We can take them out of Iraq for purposes of training.  We should do whatever has to be done to train the Iraqis and to speed up that process.  That works in conjunction with making sure the elections take place on time.  Right now
column11: the United Nations
column12: which is responsible for the elections in January
column13: has about 35 people there. Now
column14: that's compared with a much smaller country like East Timor
column15: where they had over 200 people on the ground.  You need more than 35 people to hold an election in Cleveland
column16: much less in Iraq.  And they keep saying the election's on schedule
column17: this is going to happen.  The reality is we need a new president with credibility with the rest of the world and who has a real plan for success. Success breeds contribution
column18: breeds joining the coalition.  Not only that
column19: I want to go back to what the vice president said. He attacks us about the troops. They sent 40
column20: 000 American troops into Iraq without the body armor they needed. They sent them without the armored vehicles they needed. While they were on the ground fighting
column21: they lobbied the Congress to cut their combat pay. This is the height of hypocrisy.

column3: it's hard to know where to start; there are so many inaccuracies there. The fact of the matter is the troops wouldn't have what they have today if you guys had had your way.  You talk about internationalizing the effort. They don't have a plan. Basically
column4: it's an echo.  You made the comment that the Gulf War coalition in '91 was far stronger than this. No. We had 34 countries then; we've got 30 today. We've got troops beside us.  It's hard
column5: after John Kerry referred to our allies as a coalition of the coerced and the bribed
column6: to go out and persuade people to send troops and to participate in this process.  You end up with a situation in which -- talk about demeaning. In effect
column7: you demean the sacrifice of our allies when you say it's the wrong war
column8: wrong place
column9: wrong time
column10: and oh
column11: by the way
column12: send troops.  Makes no sense at all. It's totally inconsistent. There isn't a plan there.  Our most important ally in the war on terror
column13: in Iraq specifically
column14: is Prime Minister Allawi. He came recently and addressed a joint session of Congress that I presided over with the speaker of the House.  And John Kerry rushed out immediately after his speech was over with
column15: where he came and he thanked America for our contributions and our sacrifice and pledged to hold those elections in January
column16: went out and demeaned him
column17: criticized him
column18: challenged his credibility.  That is not the way to win friends and allies. You're never going to add to the coalition with that kind of attitude.

column1: Thank you. The vice president suggests that we have the same number of countries involved now that we had in the first Gulf War. The first Gulf War cost the American people $5 billion.  And regardless of what the vice president says
column2: we're at $200 billion and counting. Not only that
column3: 90 percent of the coalition casualties
column4: Mr. Vice President
column5: the coalition casualties
column6: are American casualties. Ninety percent of the cost of this effort are being borne by American taxpayers. It is the direct result of the failures of this administration.

column1: Classic example. He won't count the sacrifice and the contribution of Iraqi allies. It's their country. They're in the fight. They're increasingly the ones out there putting their necks on the line to take back their country from the terrorists and the old regime elements that are still left. They're doing a superb job. And for you to demean their sacrifices strikes me as...

column3: I did not...

column2: because you want to be able to say that the Americans are taking 90 percent of the sacrifice. You cannot succeed in this effort if you're not willing to recognize the enormous contribution the Iraqis are increasingly making to their own future. We'll win when they take on responsibility for governance
column3: which they're doing
column4: and when the take on responsibility for their own security
column5: which they increasingly are doing.

column3: first of all
column4: to what the vice president just said
column5: and then I'll answer that question. This
column6: unfortunately -- what the vice president is telling people is inconsistent with everything they see every single day. It's a continuation of
column7: ""Well
column8: there's a strong connection between Al Qaida and Saddam Hussein.""  It's not true. It's a continuation of at least insinuating that there's some connection between 9/11 and Saddam Hussein. It's not true.  It's saying to the American people
column9: as the president said last Thursday
column10: and the vice president continues to say tonight
column11: that things are going well in Iraq
column12: contrary to what people who have been there have seen
column13: including Republican leaders
column14: contrary to what everyone in America sees on their television every day -- Americans being kidnapped
column15: people being beheaded
column16: parts of the country under the control of insurgents
column17: even today
column18: under the control of the insurgents.  The vice president has still not said anything about what Mr. Bremer said
column19: about the failure to have adequate troops
column20: the failure to be able to secure the country in the short term.  You know
column21: remember ""shock and awe""?  Look at where we are now. It is a direct result of the failure to plan
column22: the failure to have others involved in this effort. This is not an accident.  Now
column23: let me go back to your question.  If we want to do the things that need to be done to keep this country safe
column24: we can't be dragged kicking and screaming to it.  One thing that everybody does agree on is that 9/11 did change things.  But what's happened is this administration opposed the creation of a 9/11 Commission to find out why it happened and what we needed to do.  They opposed the creation of a Department of Homeland Security
column25: and then they were for it.  We can't react that way. We must be more aggressive.  With John Kerry as president of the United States
column26: we are committed to immediately implementing all of the reforms suggested by the 9/11 Commission
column27: so that we have the information we need to find terrorists and crush them before they hurt us.

column2: the story that appeared today about this report is one I asked for. I ask an awful lot of questions as part of my job as vice president. A CIA spokesman was quoted in that story as saying they had not yet reached the bottom line and there is still debate over this question of the relationship between Zarqawi and Saddam Hussein. The report also points out that at one point some of Zarqawi's people were arrested. Saddam personally intervened to have them released
column3: supposedly at the request of Zarqawi  But let's look at what we know about Mr. Zarqawi.  We know he was running a terrorist camp
column4: training terrorists in Afghanistan prior to 9/11. We know that when we went into Afghanistan that he then migrated to Baghdad. He set up shop in Baghdad
column5: where he oversaw the poisons facility up at Khurmal (ph)
column6: where the terrorists were developing ricin and other deadly substances to use.  We know he's still in Baghdad today. He is responsible for most of the major car bombings that have killed or maimed thousands of people. He's the one you will see on the evening news beheading hostages.  He is
column7: without question
column8: a bad guy. He is
column9: without question
column10: a terrorist. He was
column11: in fact
column12: in Baghdad before the war
column13: and he's in Baghdad now after the war.  The fact of the matter is that this is exactly the kind of track record we've seen over the years. We have to deal with Zarqawi by taking him out
column14: and that's exactly what we'll do.

column3: Gwen
column4: at the time
column5: I was talking specifically about this question of unilateral sanctions. What happens when we impose unilateral sanctions is
column6: unless there's a collective effort
column7: then other people move in and take advantage of the situation and you don't have any impact
column8: except to penalize American companies.  We've got sanctions on Iran now. We may well want to go to the U.N. Security Council and ask for even tougher sanctions if they don't live up to their obligations under the initial -- International Atomic Energy Agency Non-Proliferation Treaty.  We dealt with Iran differently than we have Iraq partly because Iran has not yet
column9: as Iraq did
column10: violated 12 years of resolutions by the U.N. Security Council.  We're working with the Brits and the Germans and the French
column11: who've been negotiating with the Iranians.  We recently were actively involved in a meeting with the board of governors in the International Atomic Energy Agency. And as I say
column12: there will be a follow-up meeting in November to determine whether or not Iran's living up to their commitments and obligations.  And if they aren't
column13: my guess is then the board of governors will recommend sending the whole matter to the U.N. Security Council for the application of the international sanctions
column14: which I think would be exactly the right way to go.  We're addressing North Korea on a similar basis
column15: working with the Chinese
column16: the South Koreans
column17: the Japanese and others to try to bring them around.  One of the great by-products
column18: for example
column19: of what we did in Iraq and Afghanistan is that five days after we captured Saddam Hussein
column20: Moammar Gadhafi in Libya came forward and announced that he was going to surrender all of his nuclear materials to the United States
column21: which he has done.  This was one of the biggest sources of proliferation in the world today in terms of the threat that was represented by that. The suppliers network that provided that
column22: headed by Mr. A.Q. Khan
column23: has been shut down.  We've made major progress in dealing here with a major issue with respect to nuclear proliferation. And we'll continue to press very hard on the North Koreans and the Iranians as well.

column2: the vice president talks about there being a member
column3: or someone associated with Al Qaida
column4: in Iraq. There are 60 countries who have members of Al Qaida in them. How many of those countries are we going to invade?  Not only that
column5: he talks about Iran. The reality about Iran is that Iran has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program on their watch. They ceded responsibility to dealing with it to the Europeans.  Now
column6: the vice president
column7: as you pointed out
column8: spoke out loudly for lifting the sanctions on Iraq. John Kerry and I believe we need to strengthen the sanctions on Iraq
column9: including closing the loophole that allows companies to use a subsidiary
column10: offshore subsidiaries to do business with Iran.  I mentioned Halliburton a few minute ago in connection with the $87 billion
column11: and you raised it in this question. This is relevant
column12: because he was pushing for lifting sanctions when he was CEO of Halliburton. Here's why we didn't think Halliburton should have a no-bid contract.  While he was CEO of Halliburton
column13: they paid millions of dollars in fines for providing false information on their company
column14: just like Enron and Ken Lay.  They did business with Libya and Iran
column15: two sworn enemies of the United States.  They're now under investigation for having bribed foreign officials during that period of time.  Not only that
column16: they've gotten a $7.5 billion no-bid contract in Iraq
column17: and instead of part of their money being withheld
column18: which is the way it's normally done
column19: because they're under investigation
column20: they've continued to get their money.

column3: but it's going to take more than 30 seconds.

column2: the reason they keep mentioning Halliburton is because they're trying to throw up a smokescreen. They know the charges are false. They know that if you go
column3: for example
column4: to factcheck.com (sic)
column5: an independent Web site sponsored by the University of Pennsylvania
column6: you can get the specific details with respect to Halliburton.  It's an effort that they've made repeatedly to try to confuse the voters and to raise questions
column7: but there's no substance to the charges.

column1: These are the facts. The facts are the vice president's company that he was CEO of
column2: that did business with sworn enemies of the United States
column3: paid millions of dollars in fines for providing false financial information
column4: is under investigation for bribing foreign officials.  The same company that got a $7.5 billion no-bid contract
column5: the rule is that part of their money is supposed to be withheld when they're under investigation
column6: as they are now
column7: for having overcharged the American taxpayer
column8: but they're getting every dime of their money.  I'm happy to let voters make their own decision about this.
