column3: 3)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: I do agree that we've been largely absent
column6: not entirely absent
column7: but largely absent from the peace-making process over the last four years. And let me just say a couple of preliminary things and then talk about where we are now.  First
column8: the Israeli people not only have the right to defend themselves
column9: they should defend themselves. They have an obligation to defend themselves.  I mean
column10: if I can
column11: just for a moment
column12: tell you a personal story. I was in Jerusalem a couple of years ago
column13: actually three years ago
column14: in August of 2001
column15: staying at the King David Hotel.  We left in the morning
column16: headed to the airport to leave
column17: and later in the day I found out that that same day
column18: not far from where we were staying
column19: the Sbarro Pizzeria was hit by a suicide bomber in Jerusalem. Fifteen people were killed. Six children were killed.  What are the Israeli people supposed to do? How can they continue to watch Israeli children killed by suicide bombers
column20: killed by terrorists?  They have not only the right but the obligation to defend themselves.  Now
column21: we know that the prime minister has made a decision
column22: a historic decision
column23: to unilaterally withdraw from Gaza. It's important for America to participate in helping with that process.  Now
column24: if Gaza's being used as a platform for attacking the Israeli people
column25: that has to be stopped. And Israel has a right to defend itself. They don't have a partner for peace right now. They certainly don't have a partner in Arafat
column26: and they need a legitimate partner for peace.  And I might add
column27: it is very important for America to crack down on the Saudis who have not had a public prosecution for financing terrorism since 9/11.  And it's important for America to confront the situation in Iran
column28: because Iran is an enormous threat to Israel and to the Israeli people.

column2: I want to go back to the last comment
column3: and then I'll come back to Israel-Palestine. The reason they keep trying to attack Halliburton is because they want to obscure their own record.  And Senator
column4: frankly
column5: you have a record in the Senate that's not very distinguished. You've missed 33 out of 36 meetings in the Judiciary Committee
column6: almost 70 percent of the meetings of the Intelligence Committee.  You've missed a lot of key votes: on tax policy
column7: on energy
column8: on Medicare reform.  Your hometown newspaper has taken to calling you ""Senator Gone."" You've got one of the worst attendance records in the United States Senate.  Now
column9: in my capacity as vice president
column10: I am the president of Senate
column11: the presiding officer. I'm up in the Senate most Tuesdays when they're in session.  The first time I ever met you was when you walked on the stage tonight.  In respect to Israel and Palestine
column12: Gwen
column13: the suicide bombers
column14: in part
column15: were generated by Saddam Hussein
column16: who paid $25
column17: 000 to the families of suicide bombers.  I personally think one of the reasons that we don't have as many suicide attacks today in Israel as we've had in the past is because Saddam is no longer in business.  We've been strong supporters of Israel. The president stepped forward and put in place a policy basically that said we will support the establishment of two states. First president ever to say we'll establish and support a Palestinian state nextdoor to Israelis.  But first
column18: there has to be an interlocutor you can trust and deal with. And we won't have that
column19: we don't have it now
column20: in a Yasser Arafat. There has to be reform of the Palestinian system.

column4: one of four to vote against banning plastic weapons that can pass through metal detectors.  He voted against the Department of Education. He voted against funding for Meals on Wheels for seniors. He voted against a holiday for Martin Luther King. He voted against a resolution calling for the release of Nelson Mandela in South Africa.  It's amazing to hear him criticize either my record or John Kerry's.

column2: I think his record speaks for itself. And frankly
column3: it's not very distinguished.

column3: 4)	" Well
column4: Gwen
column5: there are several things that I think need to be done and are being done. We've
column6: of course
column7: been through a difficult recession
column8: and then the aftermath of 9/11
column9: where we lost over a million jobs after that attack. But we think the key is to address some basic
column10: fundamental issues that the president's already working on.  I think probably the most successful thing we can do with respect to ending poverty is to get people jobs. There's no better antidote to poverty than a good
column11: well-paying job that allows somebody to take care of their own family.  To do that
column12: we have to make America the best place in the world to do business. And that means we've got to deal effectively with tax policy. We've got to reduce the litigation costs that are built into our society. We've got to provide the adequate medical care and make certain that we can
column13: in fact
column14: create the opportunities that are vital to that process.  I'd zero in
column15: in particular
column16: on education. I think the most important thing we can do is have a first-class public school system. I'm a product of public schools.  And the president
column17: his first legislative priority was the No Child Left Behind Act. It was the first piece of legislation we introduced.  We got it passed that first summer on a bipartisan basis. We even had Ted Kennedy on board for the effort.  And it does several things. It establishes high standards. It
column18: at the same time
column19: sets up a system of testing with respect to our school system
column20: so we can establish accountability to parents and make certain that they understand how well their students are doing. And they have the opportunity to move students out of poorly performing schools to good schools.  It strikes me that that is absolutely the heart of what needs to be done from the standpoint of education.  It's also important
column21: as we go forward in the next term
column22: we want to be able to take what we've done for elementary education and move it into the secondary education.  It's working. We've seen reports now of a reduction in the achievement gap between majority students and minority students. We're making significant progress.

column1: I thought it was about jobs and poverty. I hope we get a chance to talk about education
column2: but that's what the vice president talked about. Here's what's happened: In the time that they have been in office
column3: in the last four years
column4: 1.6 million private sector jobs have been lost
column5: 2.7 million manufacturing jobs have been lost. And it's had real consequences in places like Cleveland.  Cleveland is a wonderful
column6: distinguished city that's done a lot of great things
column7: but it has the highest poverty rate in the country. One out of almost two children in Cleveland are now living in poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column8: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column9: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  And what the most striking and startling thing is
column10: they are the first presidency in 70 years -- and I'm talking Democrats
column11: Republican
column12: presidents who led us through World War
column13: through the Korean War
column14: the Vietnam War
column15: Cold War -- every one of them created jobs until this president.  We have to do better. We have a plan. We're going to get rid of -- by the way
column16: they're for outsourcing jobs. I want to make sure people hear that
column17: the fundamental difference with us. The administration says over and over that the outsourcing of millions of American jobs is good. We're against it.  We want to get rid of tax cuts for companies sending jobs overseas. We want to balance this budget
column18: get back to fiscal responsibility. And we want to invest in the creative
column19: innovative jobs of the future.

column2: we've got 111 million American taxpayers that have benefited from our income tax cuts. We've got 33 million students who've benefited from No Child Left Behind.  We've got 40 million seniors who benefited from the reform of the Medicare system. The Democrats promised prescription drug benefits. For years they've run on that platform. They never got it done. The president got it done.  We also dropped 5 million people totally off the federal income tax rolls
column3: so they no longer have to pay any federal income tax at all.  So the story
column4: I think
column5: is a good one.  And the data he's using is old data. It's from 2003. It doesn't include any of the gains that we've made in the last years. We've added 1.7 million jobs to the economy.

column1: The vice president and president like to talk about their experience on the campaign trail. Millions of people have lost their jobs. Millions have fallen into poverty. Family incomes are down
column2: while the cost of everything is going up. Medical costs are up the highest they've ever been over the last four years. We have this mess in Iraq.  Mr. Vice President
column3: I don't think the country can take four more years of this kind of experience.

column3: 4)	" Well
column4: Gwen
column5: there are several things that I think need to be done and are being done. We've
column6: of course
column7: been through a difficult recession
column8: and then the aftermath of 9/11
column9: where we lost over a million jobs after that attack. But we think the key is to address some basic
column10: fundamental issues that the president's already working on.  I think probably the most successful thing we can do with respect to ending poverty is to get people jobs. There's no better antidote to poverty than a good
column11: well-paying job that allows somebody to take care of their own family.  To do that
column12: we have to make America the best place in the world to do business. And that means we've got to deal effectively with tax policy. We've got to reduce the litigation costs that are built into our society. We've got to provide the adequate medical care and make certain that we can
column13: in fact
column14: create the opportunities that are vital to that process.  I'd zero in
column15: in particular
column16: on education. I think the most important thing we can do is have a first-class public school system. I'm a product of public schools.  And the president
column17: his first legislative priority was the No Child Left Behind Act. It was the first piece of legislation we introduced.  We got it passed that first summer on a bipartisan basis. We even had Ted Kennedy on board for the effort.  And it does several things. It establishes high standards. It
column18: at the same time
column19: sets up a system of testing with respect to our school system
column20: so we can establish accountability to parents and make certain that they understand how well their students are doing. And they have the opportunity to move students out of poorly performing schools to good schools.  It strikes me that that is absolutely the heart of what needs to be done from the standpoint of education.  It's also important
column21: as we go forward in the next term
column22: we want to be able to take what we've done for elementary education and move it into the secondary education.  It's working. We've seen reports now of a reduction in the achievement gap between majority students and minority students. We're making significant progress.

column1: I thought it was about jobs and poverty. I hope we get a chance to talk about education

column5: 2.7 million manufacturing jobs have been lost. And it's had real consequences in places like Cleveland.  Cleveland is a wonderful
column6: distinguished city that's done a lot of great things
column7: but it has the highest poverty rate in the country. One out of almost two children in Cleveland are now living in poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column8: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column9: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  And what the most striking and startling thing is
column10: they are the first presidency in 70 years -- and I'm talking Democrats
column11: Republican
column12: presidents who led us through World War
column13: through the Korean War
column14: the Vietnam War
column15: Cold War -- every one of them created jobs until this president.  We have to do better. We have a plan. We're going to get rid of -- by the way
column16: they're for outsourcing jobs. I want to make sure people hear that
column17: the fundamental difference with us. The administration says over and over that the outsourcing of millions of American jobs is good. We're against it.  We want to get rid of tax cuts for companies sending jobs overseas. We want to balance this budget
column18: get back to fiscal responsibility. And we want to invest in the creative
column19: innovative jobs of the future.

column2: we've got 111 million American taxpayers that have benefited from our income tax cuts. We've got 33 million students who've benefited from No Child Left Behind.  We've got 40 million seniors who benefited from the reform of the Medicare system. The Democrats promised prescription drug benefits. For years they've run on that platform. They never got it done. The president got it done.  We also dropped 5 million people totally off the federal income tax rolls
column3: so they no longer have to pay any federal income tax at all.  So the story
column4: I think
column5: is a good one.  And the data he's using is old data. It's from 2003. It doesn't include any of the gains that we've made in the last years. We've added 1.7 million jobs to the economy.

column3: 4)	" Well
column4: Gwen
column5: there are several things that I think need to be done and are being done. We've
column6: of course
column7: been through a difficult recession
column8: and then the aftermath of 9/11
column9: where we lost over a million jobs after that attack. But we think the key is to address some basic
column10: fundamental issues that the president's already working on.  I think probably the most successful thing we can do with respect to ending poverty is to get people jobs. There's no better antidote to poverty than a good
column11: well-paying job that allows somebody to take care of their own family.  To do that
column12: we have to make America the best place in the world to do business. And that means we've got to deal effectively with tax policy. We've got to reduce the litigation costs that are built into our society. We've got to provide the adequate medical care and make certain that we can
column13: in fact
column14: create the opportunities that are vital to that process.  I'd zero in
column15: in particular
column16: on education. I think the most important thing we can do is have a first-class public school system. I'm a product of public schools.  And the president
column17: his first legislative priority was the No Child Left Behind Act. It was the first piece of legislation we introduced.  We got it passed that first summer on a bipartisan basis. We even had Ted Kennedy on board for the effort.  And it does several things. It establishes high standards. It
column18: at the same time
column19: sets up a system of testing with respect to our school system
column20: so we can establish accountability to parents and make certain that they understand how well their students are doing. And they have the opportunity to move students out of poorly performing schools to good schools.  It strikes me that that is absolutely the heart of what needs to be done from the standpoint of education.  It's also important
column21: as we go forward in the next term
column22: we want to be able to take what we've done for elementary education and move it into the secondary education.  It's working. We've seen reports now of a reduction in the achievement gap between majority students and minority students. We're making significant progress.

column1: I thought it was about jobs and poverty. I hope we get a chance to talk about education
column2: but that's what the vice president talked about. Here's what's happened: In the time that they have been in office
column3: in the last four years
column4: 1.6 million private sector jobs have been lost
column5: 2.7 million manufacturing jobs have been lost. And it's had real consequences in places like Cleveland.  Cleveland is a wonderful
column6: distinguished city that's done a lot of great things
column7: but it has the highest poverty rate in the country. One out of almost two children in Cleveland are now living in poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column8: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column9: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  And what the most striking and startling thing is
column10: they are the first presidency in 70 years -- and I'm talking Democrats
column11: Republican
column12: presidents who led us through World War
column13: through the Korean War
column14: the Vietnam War
column15: Cold War -- every one of them created jobs until this president.  We have to do better. We have a plan. We're going to get rid of -- by the way
column16: they're for outsourcing jobs. I want to make sure people hear that
column17: the fundamental difference with us. The administration says over and over that the outsourcing of millions of American jobs is good. We're against it.  We want to get rid of tax cuts for companies sending jobs overseas. We want to balance this budget
column18: get back to fiscal responsibility. And we want to invest in the creative
column19: innovative jobs of the future.

column2: we've got 111 million American taxpayers that have benefited from our income tax cuts. We've got 33 million students who've benefited from No Child Left Behind.  We've got 40 million seniors who benefited from the reform of the Medicare system. The Democrats promised prescription drug benefits. For years they've run on that platform. They never got it done. The president got it done.  We also dropped 5 million people totally off the federal income tax rolls
column3: so they no longer have to pay any federal income tax at all.  So the story
column4: I think
column5: is a good one.  And the data he's using is old data. It's from 2003. It doesn't include any of the gains that we've made in the last years. We've added 1.7 million jobs to the economy.

column1: The vice president and president like to talk about their experience on the campaign trail. Millions of people have lost their jobs. Millions have fallen into poverty. Family incomes are down
column2: while the cost of everything is going up. Medical costs are up the highest they've ever been over the last four years. We have this mess in Iraq.  Mr. Vice President
column3: I don't think the country can take four more years of this kind of experience.

column3: 4)	" Well
column4: Gwen
column5: there are several things that I think need to be done and are being done. We've
column6: of course
column7: been through a difficult recession
column8: and then the aftermath of 9/11
column9: where we lost over a million jobs after that attack. But we think the key is to address some basic
column10: fundamental issues that the president's already working on.  I think probably the most successful thing we can do with respect to ending poverty is to get people jobs. There's no better antidote to poverty than a good
column11: well-paying job that allows somebody to take care of their own family.  To do that
column12: we have to make America the best place in the world to do business. And that means we've got to deal effectively with tax policy. We've got to reduce the litigation costs that are built into our society. We've got to provide the adequate medical care and make certain that we can
column13: in fact
column14: create the opportunities that are vital to that process.  I'd zero in
column15: in particular
column16: on education. I think the most important thing we can do is have a first-class public school system. I'm a product of public schools.  And the president
column17: his first legislative priority was the No Child Left Behind Act. It was the first piece of legislation we introduced.  We got it passed that first summer on a bipartisan basis. We even had Ted Kennedy on board for the effort.  And it does several things. It establishes high standards. It
column18: at the same time
column19: sets up a system of testing with respect to our school system
column20: so we can establish accountability to parents and make certain that they understand how well their students are doing. And they have the opportunity to move students out of poorly performing schools to good schools.  It strikes me that that is absolutely the heart of what needs to be done from the standpoint of education.  It's also important
column21: as we go forward in the next term
column22: we want to be able to take what we've done for elementary education and move it into the secondary education.  It's working. We've seen reports now of a reduction in the achievement gap between majority students and minority students. We're making significant progress.

column6: distinguished city that's done a lot of great things
column7: but it has the highest poverty rate in the country. One out of almost two children in Cleveland are now living in poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column8: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column9: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  And what the most striking and startling thing is
column10: they are the first presidency in 70 years -- and I'm talking Democrats
column11: Republican
column12: presidents who led us through World War
column13: through the Korean War
column14: the Vietnam War
column15: Cold War -- every one of them created jobs until this president.  We have to do better. We have a plan. We're going to get rid of -- by the way
column16: they're for outsourcing jobs. I want to make sure people hear that
column17: the fundamental difference with us. The administration says over and over that the outsourcing of millions of American jobs is good. We're against it.  We want to get rid of tax cuts for companies sending jobs overseas. We want to balance this budget
column18: get back to fiscal responsibility. And we want to invest in the creative
column19: innovative jobs of the future.

column2: we've got 111 million American taxpayers that have benefited from our income tax cuts. We've got 33 million students who've benefited from No Child Left Behind.  We've got 40 million seniors who benefited from the reform of the Medicare system. The Democrats promised prescription drug benefits. For years they've run on that platform. They never got it done. The president got it done.  We also dropped 5 million people totally off the federal income tax rolls
column3: so they no longer have to pay any federal income tax at all.  So the story
column4: I think
column5: is a good one.  And the data he's using is old data. It's from 2003. It doesn't include any of the gains that we've made in the last years. We've added 1.7 million jobs to the economy.

column3: I don't think the country can take four more years of this kind of experience.

column3: 4)	" Well
column4: Gwen
column5: there are several things that I think need to be done and are being done. We've
column6: of course
column7: been through a difficult recession
column8: and then the aftermath of 9/11
column9: where we lost over a million jobs after that attack. But we think the key is to address some basic
column10: fundamental issues that the president's already working on.  I think probably the most successful thing we can do with respect to ending poverty is to get people jobs. There's no better antidote to poverty than a good
column11: well-paying job that allows somebody to take care of their own family.  To do that
column12: we have to make America the best place in the world to do business. And that means we've got to deal effectively with tax policy. We've got to reduce the litigation costs that are built into our society. We've got to provide the adequate medical care and make certain that we can
column13: in fact
column14: create the opportunities that are vital to that process.  I'd zero in
column15: in particular
column16: on education. I think the most important thing we can do is have a first-class public school system. I'm a product of public schools.  And the president
column17: his first legislative priority was the No Child Left Behind Act. It was the first piece of legislation we introduced.  We got it passed that first summer on a bipartisan basis. We even had Ted Kennedy on board for the effort.  And it does several things. It establishes high standards. It
column18: at the same time
column19: sets up a system of testing with respect to our school system
column20: so we can establish accountability to parents and make certain that they understand how well their students are doing. And they have the opportunity to move students out of poorly performing schools to good schools.  It strikes me that that is absolutely the heart of what needs to be done from the standpoint of education.  It's also important
column21: as we go forward in the next term
column22: we want to be able to take what we've done for elementary education and move it into the secondary education.  It's working. We've seen reports now of a reduction in the achievement gap between majority students and minority students. We're making significant progress.

column14: the Vietnam War

column18: get back to fiscal responsibility. And we want to invest in the creative

column3: 4)	" Well
column4: Gwen
column5: there are several things that I think need to be done and are being done. We've
column6: of course
column7: been through a difficult recession
column8: and then the aftermath of 9/11
column9: where we lost over a million jobs after that attack. But we think the key is to address some basic
column10: fundamental issues that the president's already working on.  I think probably the most successful thing we can do with respect to ending poverty is to get people jobs. There's no better antidote to poverty than a good
column11: well-paying job that allows somebody to take care of their own family.  To do that
column12: we have to make America the best place in the world to do business. And that means we've got to deal effectively with tax policy. We've got to reduce the litigation costs that are built into our society. We've got to provide the adequate medical care and make certain that we can
column13: in fact
column14: create the opportunities that are vital to that process.  I'd zero in
column15: in particular
column16: on education. I think the most important thing we can do is have a first-class public school system. I'm a product of public schools.  And the president
column17: his first legislative priority was the No Child Left Behind Act. It was the first piece of legislation we introduced.  We got it passed that first summer on a bipartisan basis. We even had Ted Kennedy on board for the effort.  And it does several things. It establishes high standards. It
column18: at the same time
column19: sets up a system of testing with respect to our school system
column20: so we can establish accountability to parents and make certain that they understand how well their students are doing. And they have the opportunity to move students out of poorly performing schools to good schools.  It strikes me that that is absolutely the heart of what needs to be done from the standpoint of education.  It's also important
column21: as we go forward in the next term
column22: we want to be able to take what we've done for elementary education and move it into the secondary education.  It's working. We've seen reports now of a reduction in the achievement gap between majority students and minority students. We're making significant progress.

column1: I thought it was about jobs and poverty. I hope we get a chance to talk about education
column2: but that's what the vice president talked about. Here's what's happened: In the time that they have been in office
column3: in the last four years
column4: 1.6 million private sector jobs have been lost
column5: 2.7 million manufacturing jobs have been lost. And it's had real consequences in places like Cleveland.  Cleveland is a wonderful
column6: distinguished city that's done a lot of great things
column7: but it has the highest poverty rate in the country. One out of almost two children in Cleveland are now living in poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column8: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  During the time that the vice president and the president have been in office
column9: 4 million more Americans have fallen into poverty.  And what the most striking and startling thing is
column10: they are the first presidency in 70 years -- and I'm talking Democrats
column11: Republican
column12: presidents who led us through World War
column13: through the Korean War
column14: the Vietnam War
column15: Cold War -- every one of them created jobs until this president.  We have to do better. We have a plan. We're going to get rid of -- by the way
column16: they're for outsourcing jobs. I want to make sure people hear that
column17: the fundamental difference with us. The administration says over and over that the outsourcing of millions of American jobs is good. We're against it.  We want to get rid of tax cuts for companies sending jobs overseas. We want to balance this budget
column18: get back to fiscal responsibility. And we want to invest in the creative
column19: innovative jobs of the future.

column2: we've got 111 million American taxpayers that have benefited from our income tax cuts. We've got 33 million students who've benefited from No Child Left Behind.  We've got 40 million seniors who benefited from the reform of the Medicare system. The Democrats promised prescription drug benefits. For years they've run on that platform. They never got it done. The president got it done.  We also dropped 5 million people totally off the federal income tax rolls
column3: so they no longer have to pay any federal income tax at all.  So the story
column4: I think
column5: is a good one.  And the data he's using is old data. It's from 2003. It doesn't include any of the gains that we've made in the last years. We've added 1.7 million jobs to the economy.

column1: The vice president and president like to talk about their experience on the campaign trail. Millions of people have lost their jobs. Millions have fallen into poverty. Family incomes are down
column2: while the cost of everything is going up. Medical costs are up the highest they've ever been over the last four years. We have this mess in Iraq.  Mr. Vice President
column3: I don't think the country can take four more years of this kind of experience.

column3: 5)	" Because we will do what they've not done. You know
column4: if you look at what's happened over the last four years
column5: we have gone from a $5 trillion projected surplus when George Bush took office to a $3 trillion projected deficit. They promised they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus aside from Social Security. Not done.  Not only that
column6: it's the biggest fiscal turnaround in American history.  And there's no end in sight. The Washington Post just reported they have several trillion dollars of additional tax cuts and spending
column7: no suggestion of what they're going to do about it.  John Kerry and I believe we have a moral responsibility not to leave trillions of debt to our children and our grandchildren.  So here's what we're going to do
column8: to answer your question.  To pay for the things that we believe need to be done -- and I hope to get the chance to talk about health care and also about education
column9: because we have plans on both of those subjects -- what we're going to do is roll back tax cuts.  And I want everyone to hear this
column10: because there have been exaggerations made on the campaign trail: Roll back tax cuts for people who make over $200
column11: 000 a year; we will do that.  We want to keep the tax cuts that are in place for people who make less than $200
column12: 000 a year and give additional tax cuts to those middle-class families
column13: tax cuts for health care
column14: tax cuts to help families pay for their college tuition
column15: tax cuts for child care.  These families are struggling and hurting
column16: and they need more tax relief
column17: not less tax relief.  But to help get us back on the path to a balanced budget
column18: we also want to get rid of some of the bureaucratic spending in Washington.  One of the amazing things that's happened is they've actually layered on more supervisory people
column19: people at the supervisory level
column20: in this government.  We also want to close some corporate loopholes.  Now
column21: I want to be honest with people. We can't eliminate this deficit. People have heard that over and over and over in four years. We cannot do it. We're in too deep a hole.  But we can cut the deficit in half. And if we move
column22: we can move this country back on a path to fiscal responsibility.

column2: the Kerry record on taxes is one basically of voting for a large number of tax increases -- 98 times in the United States Senate. There's a fundamental philosophical difference here between the president and myself
column3: who believe that we ought to let the American people keep more of what they earn and we ought to empower them to have more control over their own lives -- I think the Kerry-Edwards approach basically is to raise taxes and to give government more control over the lives of individual citizens.  We think that's the wrong way to go. There's a fundamental difference of opinion here.  They talk about the top bracket and going after only those people in the top bracket.  Well
column4: the fact of the matter is a great many of our small businesses pay taxes under the personal income taxes rather than the corporate rate. And about 900
column5: 000 small businesses will be hit if you do
column6: in fact
column7: do what they want to do with the top bracket.  That's not smart because seven out of 10 new jobs in America are created by small businesses.  You do not want to tax them. It's a bad idea to increase the burden on those folks.  The senator himself said
column8: during the course of the primaries
column9: that the Kerry plan would drive us deeper into deficit. Those were the senator's words about his running-mate.  The fact of the matter is
column10: the president and I will go forward to make the tax cuts permanent. That's good policy. That's what we ought to do. But with fiscal restraint
column11: we'll also drive the deficit down 50 percent in the course of the next five years.

column1: We are committed to cutting back anything in our programs that need to be cut back to get us back on a path to fiscal responsibility. John Kerry
column3: has voted or co-sponsored over 600 times tax cuts for the American people -- over 600 times.  And there is a philosophical difference between us and them.  We are for more tax cuts for the middle class than they're for
column4: have been for the last four years. But we are not for more tax cuts for multimillionaires. They are.  And it is a fundamental difference in what we think needs to be done in this country.

column2: the president signed an extension of middle- class tax cuts
column3: the 10 percent bracket
column4: the marriage penalty relief and the increase in the child tax credit. Senators Kerry and Edwards weren't even there to vote for it when it came to final passage.

column3: 5)	" Because we will do what they've not done. You know
column4: if you look at what's happened over the last four years
column5: we have gone from a $5 trillion projected surplus when George Bush took office to a $3 trillion projected deficit. They promised they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus aside from Social Security. Not done.  Not only that
column6: it's the biggest fiscal turnaround in American history.  And there's no end in sight. The Washington Post just reported they have several trillion dollars of additional tax cuts and spending
column7: no suggestion of what they're going to do about it.  John Kerry and I believe we have a moral responsibility not to leave trillions of debt to our children and our grandchildren.  So here's what we're going to do
column8: to answer your question.  To pay for the things that we believe need to be done -- and I hope to get the chance to talk about health care and also about education
column9: because we have plans on both of those subjects -- what we're going to do is roll back tax cuts.  And I want everyone to hear this
column10: because there have been exaggerations made on the campaign trail: Roll back tax cuts for people who make over $200
column11: 000 a year; we will do that.  We want to keep the tax cuts that are in place for people who make less than $200
column12: 000 a year and give additional tax cuts to those middle-class families
column13: tax cuts for health care
column14: tax cuts to help families pay for their college tuition
column15: tax cuts for child care.  These families are struggling and hurting
column16: and they need more tax relief
column17: not less tax relief.  But to help get us back on the path to a balanced budget
column18: we also want to get rid of some of the bureaucratic spending in Washington.  One of the amazing things that's happened is they've actually layered on more supervisory people
column19: people at the supervisory level
column20: in this government.  We also want to close some corporate loopholes.  Now
column21: I want to be honest with people. We can't eliminate this deficit. People have heard that over and over and over in four years. We cannot do it. We're in too deep a hole.  But we can cut the deficit in half. And if we move
column22: we can move this country back on a path to fiscal responsibility.

column2: the Kerry record on taxes is one basically of voting for a large number of tax increases -- 98 times in the United States Senate. There's a fundamental philosophical difference here between the president and myself
column3: who believe that we ought to let the American people keep more of what they earn and we ought to empower them to have more control over their own lives -- I think the Kerry-Edwards approach basically is to raise taxes and to give government more control over the lives of individual citizens.  We think that's the wrong way to go. There's a fundamental difference of opinion here.  They talk about the top bracket and going after only those people in the top bracket.  Well
column4: the fact of the matter is a great many of our small businesses pay taxes under the personal income taxes rather than the corporate rate. And about 900
column5: 000 small businesses will be hit if you do
column6: in fact
column7: do what they want to do with the top bracket.  That's not smart because seven out of 10 new jobs in America are created by small businesses.  You do not want to tax them. It's a bad idea to increase the burden on those folks.  The senator himself said
column8: during the course of the primaries
column9: that the Kerry plan would drive us deeper into deficit. Those were the senator's words about his running-mate.  The fact of the matter is
column10: the president and I will go forward to make the tax cuts permanent. That's good policy. That's what we ought to do. But with fiscal restraint
column11: we'll also drive the deficit down 50 percent in the course of the next five years.

column1: We are committed to cutting back anything in our programs that need to be cut back to get us back on a path to fiscal responsibility. John Kerry
column3: has voted or co-sponsored over 600 times tax cuts for the American people -- over 600 times.  And there is a philosophical difference between us and them.  We are for more tax cuts for the middle class than they're for
column4: have been for the last four years. But we are not for more tax cuts for multimillionaires. They are.  And it is a fundamental difference in what we think needs to be done in this country.

column2: the president signed an extension of middle- class tax cuts
column3: the 10 percent bracket
column4: the marriage penalty relief and the increase in the child tax credit. Senators Kerry and Edwards weren't even there to vote for it when it came to final passage.

column14: tax cuts to help families pay for their college tuition

column17: not less tax relief.  But to help get us back on the path to a balanced budget
column18: we also want to get rid of some of the bureaucratic spending in Washington.  One of the amazing things that's happened is they've actually layered on more supervisory people

We think that's the wrong way to go. There's a fundamental difference of opinion here.  They talk about the top bracket and going after only those people in the top bracket.  Well

column3: 6)	" Because we will do what they've not done. You know
column4: if you look at what's happened over the last four years
column5: we have gone from a $5 trillion projected surplus when George Bush took office to a $3 trillion projected deficit. They promised they were going to put $2 trillion of the surplus aside from Social Security. Not done.  Not only that
column6: it's the biggest fiscal turnaround in American history.  And there's no end in sight. The Washington Post just reported they have several trillion dollars of additional tax cuts and spending
column7: no suggestion of what they're going to do about it.  John Kerry and I believe we have a moral responsibility not to leave trillions of debt to our children and our grandchildren.  So here's what we're going to do
column8: to answer your question.  To pay for the things that we believe need to be done -- and I hope to get the chance to talk about health care and also about education
column9: because we have plans on both of those subjects -- what we're going to do is roll back tax cuts.  And I want everyone to hear this
column10: because there have been exaggerations made on the campaign trail: Roll back tax cuts for people who make over $200
column11: 000 a year; we will do that.  We want to keep the tax cuts that are in place for people who make less than $200
column12: 000 a year and give additional tax cuts to those middle-class families
column13: tax cuts for health care
column14: tax cuts to help families pay for their college tuition
column15: tax cuts for child care.  These families are struggling and hurting
column16: and they need more tax relief
column17: not less tax relief.  But to help get us back on the path to a balanced budget
column18: we also want to get rid of some of the bureaucratic spending in Washington.  One of the amazing things that's happened is they've actually layered on more supervisory people
column19: people at the supervisory level
column20: in this government.  We also want to close some corporate loopholes.  Now
column21: I want to be honest with people. We can't eliminate this deficit. People have heard that over and over and over in four years. We cannot do it. We're in too deep a hole.  But we can cut the deficit in half. And if we move
column22: we can move this country back on a path to fiscal responsibility.

column2: the Kerry record on taxes is one basically of voting for a large number of tax increases -- 98 times in the United States Senate. There's a fundamental philosophical difference here between the president and myself
column3: who believe that we ought to let the American people keep more of what they earn and we ought to empower them to have more control over their own lives -- I think the Kerry-Edwards approach basically is to raise taxes and to give government more control over the lives of individual citizens.  We think that's the wrong way to go. There's a fundamental difference of opinion here.  They talk about the top bracket and going after only those people in the top bracket.  Well
column4: the fact of the matter is a great many of our small businesses pay taxes under the personal income taxes rather than the corporate rate. And about 900
column5: 000 small businesses will be hit if you do
column6: in fact
column7: do what they want to do with the top bracket.  That's not smart because seven out of 10 new jobs in America are created by small businesses.  You do not want to tax them. It's a bad idea to increase the burden on those folks.  The senator himself said
column8: during the course of the primaries
column9: that the Kerry plan would drive us deeper into deficit. Those were the senator's words about his running-mate.  The fact of the matter is
column10: the president and I will go forward to make the tax cuts permanent. That's good policy. That's what we ought to do. But with fiscal restraint
column11: we'll also drive the deficit down 50 percent in the course of the next five years.

column1: We are committed to cutting back anything in our programs that need to be cut back to get us back on a path to fiscal responsibility. John Kerry
column3: has voted or co-sponsored over 600 times tax cuts for the American people -- over 600 times.  And there is a philosophical difference between us and them.  We are for more tax cuts for the middle class than they're for
column4: have been for the last four years. But we are not for more tax cuts for multimillionaires. They are.  And it is a fundamental difference in what we think needs to be done in this country.

column2: the president signed an extension of middle- class tax cuts
column3: the 10 percent bracket
column4: the marriage penalty relief and the increase in the child tax credit. Senators Kerry and Edwards weren't even there to vote for it when it came to final passage.

column3: 8)	" Well
column4: Gwen...

column2: I'm not familiar with his cases. My concern is specifically with what's happened to our medical care system because of rising malpractice insurance rates
column3: because we failed to adequately reform our medical liability structure. I was in New Mexico the other day and met with a group of OB/GYN docs.  And they were deeply concerned because they were fearful that there'd be another increase in malpractice insurance rates as a result of what they believe are frivolous lawsuits and that that would put them out of business.  And one doctor indicated that her rates have gone up so much that she's now to the point where she is screening patients. She won't take high-risk patients anymore because of the danger that that will generate a lawsuit
column4: and a lawsuit will put her out of business.  This has had a devastating impact in a lot of communities. My home state of Wyoming
column5: we've lost the top insurer of malpractice insurance in the state. The rates for a general practitioner have gone from $40
column6: 000 a year to $100
column7: 000 a year for an insurance policy.  We think this has a devastating impact on the quality of health care.  As I say
column8: high risk patients don't get covered anymore. We've lost one out of eleven OB/GYN practitioners in the country. We think it can be fixed
column9: needs to be fixed.  Now
column10: specifically
column11: what we need to do is cap non-economic damages
column12: and we also think you need to limit the awards that the trial attorneys take out of all of this. Over 50 percent of the settlements go to the attorneys and for administrating overhead.  We passed medical liability reform through the House of Representatives. It's been blocked in the Senate. Senator Kerry's voted 10 times against medical liability reform
column13: and I don't believe Senator Edwards supports it
column14: either
column15: not the kind that would be meaningful.

column3: I'm proud of the work I did on behalf of kids and families against big insurance companies
column4: big drug companies and big HMOs. We do have too many lawsuits. And the reality is there's something that we can do about it.  John Kerry and I have a plan to do something about it. We want to put more responsibility on the lawyers to require
column5: before a case
column6: malpractice
column7: which the vice president just spoke about
column8: have the case reviewed by independent experts to determine if the case is serious and meritorious before it can be filed; hold the lawyers responsible for that
column9: certify that and hold the lawyer financially responsible if they don't do it; have a three-strikes-and-you're-out rule so that a lawyer who files three of these cases without meeting this requirement loses their right to file these cases.  That way we keep the cases out of the system that don't belong in the system. They talk about frivolous cases. We believe cases that don't belong in the system should never be in the system.  But we don't believe that we should take away the right of people like Valerie Lakey
column10: who was the young girl who I represented
column11: five years old
column12: severely injured for life
column13: on a defective swimming pool drain cover.  It turns out the company knew of 12 other children who had either been killed or severely injured by the same problem. They hid it. They didn't tell anybody. They could have fixed it with a 2-cent screw. That's wrong.  John Kerry and I are always going to stand with the Valerie Lakeys of the world
column14: and not with the insurance companies.

column1: Am I personally attacked? I think the truth is that what they're doing is talking about an issue that really doesn't have a great deal to do with what's happening with medical cost in this country
column2: which I think is a very serious issue.  And I would be the first to say that what the vice president described a few minutes ago
column3: problems with malpractice premiums
column4: that's true
column5: it's real. It's very real. What doctors talk about is very serious.  And they're getting squeezed from both sides. I mean
column6: because
column7: they have trouble getting reimbursed
column8: first of all
column9: for the care that they provide
column10: you know
column11: from the government or from health-care companies. And
column12: on the flip side
column13: their malpractice costs are going up.  That's very real
column14: which is why we have proposed a plan to keep cases out of the system that don't belong there.  But it's very important to put this in context. Because
column15: in context
column16: everything they're proposing
column17: according to the bipartisan Congressional Budget Office
column18: amounts to about half of 1 percent of health-care costs in this country -- half of 1 percent.  We have double-digit inflation in health care costs. We've seen the largest rise in medical costs in the last four years in the country's history: $3
column19: 500 nationally. And nobody who's watching this debate needs me to explain this to them. They know it.  Medicare premiums are up 17 percent on their watch. Again
column20: largest increase in Medicare premiums in the history of Medicare.  We think we have a plan to keep cases that don't belong in the system out
column21: but we also do what they haven't done.  Five million Americans have lost their health care coverage. Medical costs are skyrocketing. We have a serious health care plan to bring down costs for everybody
column22: to cover millions more Americans and to actually stand up to drug companies and insurance companies which this administration has been unwilling to do.

column2: we think lawsuit abuse is a serious problem in this country. We think we badly need tort reform. I was in Minnesota the other day
column3: where I visited an aircraft manufacturing plant. It's a great success story. This is a company that started 20 years ago with nothing. Today they're the second- leading producer of piston-driven aircraft in the country.  He told me that if it weren't for the increased cost of his liability insurance
column4: in this case product liability
column5: he could hire 200 more people in his factory. We've built into the system enormous costs as a result of our practice with respect to litigation. We have to find ways to get a handle on it.  He mentioned Medicare up 17 percent
column6: somehow that that was something we caused. No. The 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums was the direct result of a statute adopted in 1997. John Kerry voted for it.  It establishes the formula for Part B of Medicare that says
column7: in effect
column8: it has to cover 25 percent of the cost of the program. And the reason the money had to go into the trust fund was to make certain that we could cover those eligible for benefits.  While you were in private practice in law and as a senator
column9: you had the advantage of a special tax loophole
column10: Subchapter S corporation
column11: which you set up so you could avoid paying $600
column12: 000 in Medicare taxes that would have gone into the fund.  And it's those kinds of loopholes that necessitate a premium increase under the law that was enacted in 1997
column13: supported by John Kerry.

column3: I have paid all the taxes that I owe. When the vice president was CEO of Halliburton
column4: they took advantage of every offshore loophole available. They had multiple offshore companies that were avoiding taxes.  Those are the kind of things that ought to be closed. They ought to be closed. They ought to be closed for anybody. They ought to be closed whether they're personal
column5: and they ought to be closed whether they apply to a corporation.  But the reality is health care costs are going up every day for the American people
column6: and I hope we're going to get a chance to talk more about health care.

column1: We've done a lot to reduce the cost of health care. The Medicare drug benefit that we'll be providing to seniors beginning in '06 will provide upwards to $1
column2: 300 a year to help them buy prescription drugs. The drug savings -- drug discount card that's now available saves an estimated 15 percent to 30 percent off the cost of prescription drugs for senior citizens.  So we're moving in as many areas as we can to make certain we hold down and reduce the health care costs.

column3: 8)	" Well
column4: Gwen...

column2: I'm not familiar with his cases. My concern is specifically with what's happened to our medical care system because of rising malpractice insurance rates
column3: because we failed to adequately reform our medical liability structure. I was in New Mexico the other day and met with a group of OB/GYN docs.  And they were deeply concerned because they were fearful that there'd be another increase in malpractice insurance rates as a result of what they believe are frivolous lawsuits and that that would put them out of business.  And one doctor indicated that her rates have gone up so much that she's now to the point where she is screening patients. She won't take high-risk patients anymore because of the danger that that will generate a lawsuit
column4: and a lawsuit will put her out of business.  This has had a devastating impact in a lot of communities. My home state of Wyoming
column5: we've lost the top insurer of malpractice insurance in the state. The rates for a general practitioner have gone from $40
column6: 000 a year to $100
column7: 000 a year for an insurance policy.  We think this has a devastating impact on the quality of health care.  As I say
column8: high risk patients don't get covered anymore. We've lost one out of eleven OB/GYN practitioners in the country. We think it can be fixed
column9: needs to be fixed.  Now
column10: specifically
column11: what we need to do is cap non-economic damages
column12: and we also think you need to limit the awards that the trial attorneys take out of all of this. Over 50 percent of the settlements go to the attorneys and for administrating overhead.  We passed medical liability reform through the House of Representatives. It's been blocked in the Senate. Senator Kerry's voted 10 times against medical liability reform
column13: and I don't believe Senator Edwards supports it
column14: either
column15: not the kind that would be meaningful.

column3: I'm proud of the work I did on behalf of kids and families against big insurance companies
column4: big drug companies and big HMOs. We do have too many lawsuits. And the reality is there's something that we can do about it.  John Kerry and I have a plan to do something about it. We want to put more responsibility on the lawyers to require
column5: before a case
column6: malpractice
column7: which the vice president just spoke about
column8: have the case reviewed by independent experts to determine if the case is serious and meritorious before it can be filed; hold the lawyers responsible for that
column9: certify that and hold the lawyer financially responsible if they don't do it; have a three-strikes-and-you're-out rule so that a lawyer who files three of these cases without meeting this requirement loses their right to file these cases.  That way we keep the cases out of the system that don't belong in the system. They talk about frivolous cases. We believe cases that don't belong in the system should never be in the system.  But we don't believe that we should take away the right of people like Valerie Lakey
column10: who was the young girl who I represented
column11: five years old
column12: severely injured for life
column13: on a defective swimming pool drain cover.  It turns out the company knew of 12 other children who had either been killed or severely injured by the same problem. They hid it. They didn't tell anybody. They could have fixed it with a 2-cent screw. That's wrong.  John Kerry and I are always going to stand with the Valerie Lakeys of the world
column14: and not with the insurance companies.

column1: Am I personally attacked? I think the truth is that what they're doing is talking about an issue that really doesn't have a great deal to do with what's happening with medical cost in this country
column2: which I think is a very serious issue.  And I would be the first to say that what the vice president described a few minutes ago
column3: problems with malpractice premiums
column4: that's true
column5: it's real. It's very real. What doctors talk about is very serious.  And they're getting squeezed from both sides. I mean
column6: because
column7: they have trouble getting reimbursed
column8: first of all
column9: for the care that they provide
column10: you know
column11: from the government or from health-care companies. And
column12: on the flip side
column13: their malpractice costs are going up.  That's very real
column14: which is why we have proposed a plan to keep cases out of the system that don't belong there.  But it's very important to put this in context. Because
column15: in context
column16: everything they're proposing
column17: according to the bipartisan Congressional Budget Office
column18: amounts to about half of 1 percent of health-care costs in this country -- half of 1 percent.  We have double-digit inflation in health care costs. We've seen the largest rise in medical costs in the last four years in the country's history: $3
column19: 500 nationally. And nobody who's watching this debate needs me to explain this to them. They know it.  Medicare premiums are up 17 percent on their watch. Again
column20: largest increase in Medicare premiums in the history of Medicare.  We think we have a plan to keep cases that don't belong in the system out
column21: but we also do what they haven't done.  Five million Americans have lost their health care coverage. Medical costs are skyrocketing. We have a serious health care plan to bring down costs for everybody
column22: to cover millions more Americans and to actually stand up to drug companies and insurance companies which this administration has been unwilling to do.

column2: we think lawsuit abuse is a serious problem in this country. We think we badly need tort reform. I was in Minnesota the other day
column3: where I visited an aircraft manufacturing plant. It's a great success story. This is a company that started 20 years ago with nothing. Today they're the second- leading producer of piston-driven aircraft in the country.  He told me that if it weren't for the increased cost of his liability insurance
column4: in this case product liability
column5: he could hire 200 more people in his factory. We've built into the system enormous costs as a result of our practice with respect to litigation. We have to find ways to get a handle on it.  He mentioned Medicare up 17 percent
column6: somehow that that was something we caused. No. The 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums was the direct result of a statute adopted in 1997. John Kerry voted for it.  It establishes the formula for Part B of Medicare that says
column7: in effect
column8: it has to cover 25 percent of the cost of the program. And the reason the money had to go into the trust fund was to make certain that we could cover those eligible for benefits.  While you were in private practice in law and as a senator
column9: you had the advantage of a special tax loophole
column10: Subchapter S corporation
column11: which you set up so you could avoid paying $600
column12: 000 in Medicare taxes that would have gone into the fund.  And it's those kinds of loopholes that necessitate a premium increase under the law that was enacted in 1997
column13: supported by John Kerry.

column3: I have paid all the taxes that I owe. When the vice president was CEO of Halliburton
column4: they took advantage of every offshore loophole available. They had multiple offshore companies that were avoiding taxes.  Those are the kind of things that ought to be closed. They ought to be closed. They ought to be closed for anybody. They ought to be closed whether they're personal
column5: and they ought to be closed whether they apply to a corporation.  But the reality is health care costs are going up every day for the American people
column6: and I hope we're going to get a chance to talk more about health care.

column1: We've done a lot to reduce the cost of health care. The Medicare drug benefit that we'll be providing to seniors beginning in '06 will provide upwards to $1
column2: 300 a year to help them buy prescription drugs. The drug savings -- drug discount card that's now available saves an estimated 15 percent to 30 percent off the cost of prescription drugs for senior citizens.  So we're moving in as many areas as we can to make certain we hold down and reduce the health care costs.

column1: When the vice president was CEO of Halliburton, they took advantage of every offshore loophole available.
